151150347.review:
I completed the game because I felt like I had to, but didn't really enjoy it much. For context, I saw a few reviews saying "It gets really dark". That, paired with the videos and the "horror" tag made me think it would be a horror game with a cutesy look, which seemed like an awesome concept. But it's really not, it's more of a dialogue simulator and the story does get vaguely dark at some point, but it never stops being somewhat lighthearted and charming. 

The game play is not very enjoyable, it's basically press F on various NPCs until you get a sprinkle of lore and a dash of actual progress in the story. Part 2 was especially slow. The controls are a bit annoying. If you were wondering, you have to hold the space bar to make bigger jumps. I only figured that out at the end of the game. 

I don't want to be too critical, so here is some praise:
-Graphics are really cute and pretty
-Some serious themes are featured, although never in too much depth
-The characters are all very endearing and memorable

So basically if you like interactive novel games with cute graphics and mini-games you will enjoy this. If you expected a puzzle-based side scrolling horror game like I did, you will be disappointed. 

Finally, I didn't personally relate to the story and setting, but I can see how if you grew up in a small town knowing everyone's name, you might enjoy this.

This game deeply affected me as a person. 

A rich, vibrant, animated world. Charming characters. A wealth of branching paths.

A deep yearning for what used to be. Something that can't ever be found again. People who have moved on. A main character who can't.

There were far too many situations that reduced me to a blubbering idiot. Everything is wholly relatable yet strangely unique.

This is one of the best games of all time. Now that the spiritual successor to it has been shuttered indefinitely, this is all we have. Please, cherish it.

150451481.review:
In most games nowadays, most characters honestly don't make me feel anything for them. This isn't the case for Night in the Woods. Every character has fully fleshed out personalities that are realistic and interesting, and shows a lot of background for every character you come across. The environments are beautifully crafted with vibrant colors and leave a lot of room for exploration with such a small area to move around in. Once you start learning more about your friends, people in town, your family, and even yourself, the world grows and helps you connect more with it. Being from a small Midwest town like Possum Springs, and having gone through some similar stuff that some of the characters have, it hits very close to home for me and a lot of other fans. The music is perfect for the setting, the middle of fall to early winter, and when things get more serious in the story and with your friendships, the soundtrack helps reflect that. This is THE game to play during fall, best played around Halloween, as a lot of the story takes place in the days around Halloween and shortly after. A 10/10 experience for sure

149965681.review:
I'm more mixed than outright negative on this one. It has the potential to be good, a slice of life story with some creepy unexplainable goings ons, but it misses the target at almost every turn. You can definitely still have about 5-8 hours of middling enjoyment though, but there are still issues. 

Pros
-It's a side scrolling social story game, like Oxenfree. The main chast is limited and focused with a few supporting characters. This is kept simple and works ok.

-The actual mystery is interesting, but it took over half the game before that set in. 

-The art style works well enough and is kind of relaxing. 

Cons
There is zero voice acting and characters tend to rble on about nothing, like they're attempting to use the typical self deprecating humble bragging gen Z humor popular with kids these days. It would be ok if it was just a few characters, but it's all of them, except for Mae's (the main character) parents. 

-You play the whole game as Mae and she is supremely unlikable. The game wants you to believe she has "trauma" and is suffering from mental illness but what you get is the most surface level exploration of that. Really, it just feels like Mae never grew up and refuses to learn anything because she already has it all figured out. She makes everyone upset, hurts everyone, and insults authority figures regularly. It's all the very cringy, fight the power stuff we have seen a million times. 

-The story. I know that was a pro, but it took legitimately over half of the game before it picks up, and then it's over. The pacing was just off, and I found myself playing in ten minute increments over the course of a month or more. It just wasn't engrossing to me, and that will depend on you. 

-There is quite a lot of social messaging. It is clear which side of the political aisle the developers are on and they make it very clear to you. If you don't mind having standard left wing politics in your games than you will be ok. 

Overall I like aspects of the late game, hate the early game, and somewhat dislike everything else. I wouldn't in good conscience recommend this to anyone I know personally.

148109927.review:
[b]"Night in the Woods" is an emotional story about the anxiety of youth as growing and struggles of the working class in a small regional community. The colorful town of "Possum Springs" offers a depressing and cheerful atmosphere simultaneously, while the plot jumps between reality and dreams. Characters have vivid personalities, rich backstories and it's really interesting to watch the complex, evolving relationships between them. Yet, the gameplay has some issues. Too much walking at the same screens can get boring, while sometimes you feel like hanging around aimlessly hoping that plot will unfold by itself. Also, mini games look like random fillers that don't offer much things. Despite its flaws, it's a unique, poetic experience that offers plenty food for though.


Manometer: 7/10[/b]


The good
- Nice, minimalistic visuals with geometrical 2d graphics and vivid colors.
- The town of "Possum Springs" is well designed offering both a depressing and cheerful atmosphere at the same time. The town changes slightly with the season or the weather and is populated with characters, animals and animated things that make it look alive.
- An emotional story of human relationships as the protagonist, Mae discovers adultness and grown ups life through a series of unexpected events. Storytelling is nice full of surreal, dreamy scenes and moments that look insignificant but have many things to tell.
- Well built main characters with vivid personalities and rich backstories. It's great to watch the relationship between them changing and evolving by the time.
- Although some of the dialogues are too cute, almost childish, they're well written, interesting and at some points really poetic.
- Good, calm music that accompanies Mae through her adventures. During dreams music is even better creating a mysterious atmosphere.
- It has some moments with pretty good, inspiring sense of humor.
- Simplistic, yet smooth, cute animations.
- Most mini games are boring but few of them, like playing the bass, have fun. The little hack and slash game on your laptop is great too.
- It opens up some serious social and political issues like daily problems of the working class, struggling of people to survive in a small community, those who face psychological problems, the anxiety of youth as growing, generations' gap, importance of friendship.

The bad
- Too much walking left and right at the same few screens. You go to almost to the same places every day expecting for something new to pop up. Some procedures tend to get monotonous like talking to your mom every morning and to your dad every night. Sometimes you feel like no having a specific purpose, instead you just hang around doing staff with your friends and hoping that the plot will unfold by itself.
- Boring, almost childish mini games that look like shallow fillers. It's like the developers didn't know how to extent the playtime and put random stuff in there.
- Commenting on serious topics like growing in a world of adults is accomplished via cheap solutions like transforming Mae, the protagonist, into an innocent, too naive character for her age, usually with no awareness of the consequences of what she does or says.
- Black loading screens of four to six seconds duration between most of the screens are annoying and almost ruin the vibe you're into.

147818895.review:
I think people who come into this game expecting a tight story are missing what Night in the Woods is really about. It cares a great deal less about the dark goings-on in the town than it does Mae's internal reality, her relationships and her understanding of herself. Night in the Woods is about Mae building and rebuilding the relationships that have been damaged by her mental illness, with her friends, with her mother and father, and with her town itself. 

Night in the Woods is a more intensely political game than any I've played. The easiest point of comparison for me is Disco Elysium. Possum Springs, the setting of the game, is a dying rust belt town, and we see over and over again throughout the game the way it's crumbling away. As Mae explores the town each day she gains knowledge about not only her friends' personal lives, but about the history of Possum Springs itself. Characters who speak to Mae frequently lament the loss of unions, and observe that the bosses at the few businesses left in town would fire anyone who even tried to organize their workers.  A character tells Mae about her grandfather trashing the car of a visiting mining executive.  That same mine has a familiar history, made up of lethal accidents caused by the bosses' cost-cutting and indifference, strikes violently broken by the military, and a brief period of prosperity after the unions got their way. The loss of that prosperity is illustrated again and again by each character. Poverty is woven into each character's their lives and story, from Mae's parents' anxiety about the second mortgage they took out to pay for her college, to Bea's desperate envy of Mae's educational opportunity and anger at her for squandering them. It's shown through small moments, and dialogue--Bea laments that austerity and budget cuts mean that basic infrastructure repairs, including to the washed-out bridges out of town, aren't being carried out.  A local WPA-style mural depicting heroic miners is defaced, and when Mae confronts the culprit they struggle to articulate their anger over a promise that has been betrayed.  The new pastor at the church tries to get permission to let a homeless drifter sleep in the basement, but the chamber of commerce, desperate to project an image of progress that might lure in new jobs, turns her down.  Mae's acquaintance Selmers writes "short, cute" poems about benign topics, but when she appears at a poetry reading she delivers an enraged diatribe about the poverty she's living in. 

Mae's reckoning with mental illness, dissociation, and especially psychosis resonated deeply with me as a player with schizophrenia. I really liked the moment when she angrily tells a friend's grandmother that "I'm not just a f*cking shell for my problems to walk around in." The game shows that the personal is also the political, refusing to let Mae's mental illness stand apart from the political reality of her town. There's a genuinely sickening reveal late in the game that the doctor everyone has referenced, who's been treating Mae's illness by advising her to journal, isn't a psychiatrist at all, but a GP-and-dentist. Mae's continued struggles aren't just about her being unable or unwilling to engage in treatment, they're about a complete lack of treatment options available to her in Possum Springs. 

When Mae finally confronts the monster at the end of the game she finds that it both is and isn't a supernatural creature, is and isn't a response to the impending death of Possum Springs as a town. There's an Eldritch creature, but there are also people who've allowed themselves to become something inhuman in response to what's happening in Possum Springs. Mae has a vision of her house swept away, abandoned, Possum Springs consisting only of empty fields. It's a common enough image from cosmic horror, human efforts rendered nonexistent, but it's also reflective of the more mundane fears the characters have, of Possum Springs being unable to survive without the mines, becoming a ghost town. When Mae confronts the creature, all the things she's been struggling with, from the Eldritch horror to her mental illness to her bleak future prospects, combine into one image, a tiny creature facing an immense, powerful being that doesn't care about it.  There's no choice you can make here, but it's here that the choices you've made throughout the game to let Mae meander, learn about the town and about herself and her friends, imbue the scene with added meaning and significance. 

Night in the Woods has so much meaning, so much to say about politics and the realities of dying towns. Exploring the game is perfect in the autumn. I expect I'll come back to it every year. I highly recommend.

147768412.review:
After spending 12 hours playing this game I am sad to report that it did not click for me on an emotional or mechanical level at all. I do not like saying this because I don’t enjoy tearing games down and I was genuinely looking forward to playing this, but outside of the art direction, music and Demontower minigame, Night in the Woods did not appeal to me in the way I was hoping it would.

The story, for what little there is, is generally unfocused and lacking in any real urgency, drama or stakes for roughly 85% of the story. I understand that this is a slice-of-life, slowburn type of deal and I was not expecting the story to hook me immediately. The vibes for the first hour or so were pretty good, but as the game progressed I was hoping the story would naturally develop into something more interesting and I was left wanting until the last quarter of the game. I can only speak for myself of course, but eventually your story needs a hook and this story barely has even that for most of its runtime.

If the characters of Night in the Woods were more interesting and fascinating this glacial pacing could’ve been acceptable to me, unfortunately the characters do not fare much better either. I enjoyed talking to Gregg, Bea and Candy. The rest of the main and supporting cast were not very interesting or developed. I found Mae, the main character of the game to be a conflicting presence in the story. She is deeply troubled, lacking any real focus in her life, depressed and her general dissociation from the real world was initially compelling and I did see parts of myself in her character when I was younger. Sadly, as the game progressed her responses to her friends' issues rubbed me the wrong way and I found her to be increasingly less relatable as the game pushed forward. I didn’t dislike her presence in the story, but by the end of the game I was very indifferent to her overall.

The story touches on topics like paranormal activity, the cruel indifference of capitalism, mental illness, cults and the expectations of being an adult in a world that does not care for you.

Somehow, this game did not click for me despite it seeming tailor made for me based on these topics and yet I felt underwhelmed after completing it. Why is that? It’s hard to fully pin down in an easily digestible sentence, but I think the writing wasn’t interested in exploring these concepts in a way that was interesting.

At the very least, the game did not resonate with me in the same way it did for most other players. I initially assumed the slow start would eventually pay off. It did not. The ending was also fairly abrupt and I did not feel satisfied with its conclusion.

Here’s the thing though, most people who play this do genuinely see something special about it even if I personally did not. I do not even fully regret playing it, but I think I could’ve stopped playing it around the 3 or 4 hour mark and achieved the same level of satisfaction from it that I did after completing it. If you want an adventure game that is cute, has quirky dialogue and is running entirely on vibes, you will probably find NITW to be a good time. If you expect the game to be anything more than that, you might be a little disappointed with the overall experience.

Rest in peace, Alec Holowka

147110463.review:
[h1] Not for Everyone [/h1]
It's not for everyone. I originally bought the game for the nostalgic feeling i got for Jacksepticeye's playthrough from years ago (i hadn't watched all of it) and the artstyle the game offers. The thing is, this game is incredibly, like really SLOW. I'm not just referring to the chapters' slow progression but also the inabilty the game mechanics show of getting around fast or at the very least more dynamicly. And the jump mechanic, my god, it made me tear off my hair at certain points in the game because getting the jump to work you want it to can be the hardest thing this game expects of you in certain places. You moved too fast? Whoops you have fallen off the ledge. You missed one pixel on the platform you want to land on? Whoops you have fallen at the bottom of the map do that all again. People with 'Getting Over It' trauma are guaranteed to have moments of their PTSD flairing up just because of this terrible jump control. As for the story being slow, its extremely tiring running around for hours with nothing interesting happening in the story. Running around isn't relaxing either since the game's main focus is the story behind what's happening around the town. We are given a literal arm from the start to spike up the mystery and what happens for a long while after? You do errands for HOURS to pick the ending. Yes, this game has its unique charm that will appeal to people of a certain niche, but the game is not an extremely good game with flaws: It's an alright game with flaws. Being a comic would have been much better suited for its story.

146557720.review: I am obsessed with this game, it's been my main hyperfixation for the past month, although i originally found the game when it launched, so i've obviously known about it, and known the story for YEARS, but it's been so incredibly amazing to replay this game over and over, and finding every single detail i can in the game. trying to get every achievment, and find out as much as i possibly can about the story, the ingame folklore, the characters backgrounds, the existential dread and meaning of this game. It's gotten me through a very disorienting period of near-psychosis levels of mania and depression, and made me feel seen in a way i haven't felt in any game before. I relate so intensely with nearly every character in this game, especially Mae herself. I also love the blatant but not stereotyped queerness of the main characters, and how everything just feels so real and natural, and like home, even though it's nothing like where i'm from, but i still somehow feel so connected to everything that happens there. The game is beautifully written, illustrated, and the music is perfect for it. Everything about this game just perfecctly encapsulates the feeling of that coming of age existential dread so many of us feel. And that feeling of emptiness and impending doom, of how everything is going to shit and none of us can do anything about. Wanting nothing more than for our existence to hurt to prove that it's real and it mattered. the hopelessness of leaving home, only to have a complete breakdown and ending up right back where you started. Stuck. And yet, realizing that you don't need to have a reason to live in order to do it. You can just exist, and thats ok. There are really awful things happening right under our noses all the time, and the only way we'd find out is by being in the wrong place at the wrong time, and thats enough for everything we ever knew about our surroundings so just falter into this meaningless void that we suddenly know nothing about. everything is just shapes and things lose meaning, until everything eventually goes back to normal again and you forget there was anything wrong in the first place. at least thats how it feels to replay this game over and over, because it's exactly like waking up everyday as if yesterday never happened.

146518257.review:
Steam Cloud isn't configured to sync between Windows and Linux, so I have to take extra steps to get it working. Far as I can tell, this is because the game syncs seperate Linux, Windows and Mac save data, but doesn't save between the OSs. Fixing this is not hard and the devs could do it in 5 minutes.

"But you're not a game dev! How do you know that??"

Because I read 2 paragraphs of documentation. This, my dear developers, is how you fix this issue:
1. Go to your Steamworks App Admin panel, and go to "Steam Cloud Settings"
2. Go to "Root Overrides"
3. Add a new override
4. Set the override to "WinAppDataLocalLow", OS to "Linux + SteamOS", and new root to "LinuxHome"
5. Set Add/Replace Path to ".config/unity3d/Infinite Fall/Night in the Woods" and check the box labelled "Replace Path"
6. Repeat this process for the other paths
7. Repeat this for the applicable Mac paths as well, if you wish to get this working for Mac users too

Ideally, at this point, under the root override should be a little blurb reading
[b]Preview:[/b] %USERPROFILE%/AppData/LocalLow/Infinite Fall/Night in the Woods [b]maps to[/b] ~/.config/unity3d/Infinite Fall/Night in the Woods
or whatever the equivalent is for the path you're setting up at that time. It should be pretty self-explanitory.

8. Remove the corresponding Linux and/or Mac saves from the "Root Paths" area; [b]ROOT PATHS DO NOT SAVE BETWEEN PLATFORMS, ROOT OVERRIDES DO.[/b]

If these instructions were followed (don't forget to make it developer-only while testing!), ideally saves should save between Windows and Linux, removing the need to run the Windows version on Linux in order for cloud saves to work properly. I beg of you developers, I told you what to do, all you need is for just one of you to do it.

146100876.review:
This game appeared on my way 5 years ago. I don't remember the reasons that led to its appearance, but I guess it was accompanied by the death of Alec Holowka. Which was and still is a effed up event, I should say. Since then I decided to taste that game someday because it looked pretty, had good music and something promised a great experience, which is a thing I've always loved about games as a form of art. Buuut back then I was interested in other things, playing Undertale and reading "The catcher in the rye" and living my teenage life. There was nothing that encouraged me to start NITW, until recently.

So this autumn, as I was going back to university and having experienced one shitty novel game in my life the day before, I found myself here. The game that prompted me to run this one was about high school almost-graduating dinosaurs who played in a band and had inner crises while an asteroid flew at them, and the way it was all presented in the story really upset me. I was in rage, 'cause characters acted unmatured in a bad way and noone of their speech about life, losing the goal and getting lost in a world of capitalism made me believe them. And at that very moment the phrase "I'd rather play Night in the Woods" popped into my head, and then the decision was made to finally familiarise myself with it.

For me, someone who is as old as May and has tried many complex stories, the plot of this game was phenomenal. It really feels like re-reading a novel by Salinger, as if Caulfield had graduated from high school and happened to live in our time. You really can taste that upseting feeling even when characters are goofing around - it's their way of dealing with adulthood. And none of this has to do with cartoonish style: cute cats and animals who says only "boop" and "whoopa" talks about serious shit [spoiler] (like Mae's "Everything is just shapes", Bea's lack of normal life, parent issues for Angus, and the general dying of Possum Springs) [/spoiler] that it makes you drop your jaw. I'm drawing a parallel between these two stories because I have the same feelings about them: I understand the main character, I'm invested in their world and topics that the author has put, but I am not able to read them; the story seems like a regular slice of life, but it touches on so many controversial themes of our life that I don't know where to begin to grasp it. And because of that, I feel really lost as I don't know how to talk about this piece of art even in this 'review'.

I really want to understand NITW, but I'm feeling like I can't do it yet. But, as the old Janitor said:
[spoiler] "In my experience big things don't teach you anything. But they make you something. And sometimes you gotta wait a while and see what come off it." [/spoiler] 

And so I will. What about the rest, I really think people should go through this adventure themselves, 'cause the experience like after reading a good novel are all that remains after The End of Everything.

Let me start out by saying that I %100 recommend this game to anyone, even if you don't want to buy it here. Get it using whatever method you want and play it.

This game has [b]THE[/b] best character writing I've seen. Not "in a game" or "this year" I'll add. There are very few games that genuinely make me happy to see a new character which I've not talked to yet. That's not even taking into account the main cast which is just in a whole another level.

There's a good chunk of side content, secrets, and some platforming. You won't be coming across that much pure gameplay sections which is fine I'd say. The core of this game is it's story

The art-style is simply great. It will never strain your eyes, is always pleasant to look at, and expresses the tones for a scene perfectly

The soundtrack is top tier. It's been in every iteration of my main playlist ever since I first listened to it. If you're unsure about whether you should play the game or not just listen to a few pieces from the OST. Astral Alley, Dusk Stars, and Rainy Day are my personal favorites. 

While on the topic of music there's something I want to mention, mostly for the returning fans. There are some who don't want to pay money for the game because of what happened with Alec Holowka. I don't blame anyone for having that opinion nor it's opposite. I can only say that I don't know him or his life. I just appreciate his contribution to a game I love very much.

The main thing to know about this game is that gameplay-wise, it's really more akin to a visual novel. There's some platforming and minigames and stuff, but most of the game is running around looking for dialogue.

That being said, this game is incredible. The characters are all entertaining and very well-written, the music is top-tier, the art is great, and the story (while definitely confusing) is fun to unravel

144539108.review:
I wouldn’t be surprised if some people found Night in the Woods boring. There is not much “gameplay” to speak of aside from some light platforming and a short rhythm section. What it does have though is one of the better stories I have come across in recent memory. It’s characters go through very relatable issues and aside from a couple plot twists is grounded in more reality than most games dare to dream of. The game puts you in the shoes of Mae who has just dropped out of college and moved back in with her parents and is trying to reconnect with friends while trying to navigate strange events happening in town.

	I didn’t enjoy the main character at times as she is pretty much a screw up who doesn’t realize how childish she is being and is pretty selfish at times. That being said I see it as an authentic character as many people are like this and there is nothing saying  I have to like a main character to enjoy a game. The supporting cast of her parents and her home town friends are all interesting in their own ways and I liked  learning more about them as the story moved forward. The game consists of exploring around town talking to your friends, townsfolk and your parents. Depending on which friends you talk with will decide whose story you see the most of. Talking with certain townsfolk will shed more light on them as well. When you go to bed each night there is a dream section that is based around platforming sections to find the exit to the dream. The platforming sections are well done aside from the odd time I found them hard to navigate. They have a creepy quality about them and a great soundtrack. In between dealing with friends you can take part in voluntary mini games such as a 2D action game on Mae’s laptop and taking part in band practice with friends. Luckily the band practice can be skipped without consequence because it is like playing Rock Band which I despise. The game’s art direction was well done. It’s got a unique style to it that isn’t quite cell shaded or realistic, somewhere in between the two. There is no voice acting but I didn’t find this to be a bad thing. I will say that, while the overall story was fantastic, the last 15 minutes of the game felt rushed and left certain plot lines unfinished in my eyes. There are a lot of dialogue choices you get to make when talking to people, how much they affect the story I’m unsure of. I also wish there was some more choice in the dialogue sections as I would have liked to do things differently than any way I was given, especially near the end.

	I played Night in the Woods on Linux. It never crashed on me once.  Alt-Tab didn’t work for me. There were no graphics options to speak of to adjust aside from choosing resolution and choosing between full-screen and windowed mode. I get that spectacular graphics were not a high priority for the developers, they weren’t shooting to make the next Crysis, but being able to crank up AA, AF, etc is kind of a standard feature on PC games.  Even though there was no v-sync setting the game respected my refresh rate. There were no manual saves allowed. It says that you can “save and quit” at any time but “saving” means dumping you at the last checkpoint and the game doesn’t do a good job of letting you know when those are happening so often I had to repeat little bits. The game never lagged on me at all and was smooth as butter. I was able to use my Logitech F310 without issue aside from the button prompts still being for a keyboard.

Game Engine: Unity
Graphics API: OpenGL

Game Version Played: Build 406

GPU Usage: 0-100 %

	Overall Night in the Woods was a great experience. It had a wonderful story full of great characters, was very stable, had great art and soundtrack. I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend it. Those who enjoy games like Oxenfree, Life is Strange, Gone Home and other games that focus on Story will probably love Night in the Woods. It took me six hours and fifty five minutes to finish the game. There are no difficulty settings. I paid $19.99 USD for it and I found it was well worth the price.

My Score: 8.5/10

Overall amazing game. I love the characters, the dialogue, the music, the whole aesthetic. 

I was expecting a bit more a "mystery" and a real definitive conclusion to everything, so I do feel it lacked a bit in story. There's a lot hanging out, wondering around, and a quite a bit of dialogue - some of which seems a bit unnecessary. Some of it is character building, but during my second playthrough some of the text felt like a slog to get through. 

It ends sorta unexpectedly. I can't help but to feel the ending maybe wasn't planned or they could've ran out of time. Not to mention, quite a few plot points go unanswered - but maybe that was intentional - maybe not?

Nitpicks aside, I loved Night in the Woods. It's one of my favorite games I've played in the past few years.  Would definitely recommend. Also, knowing what happened to the creator the game, it added an extra dark layer when experiencing Mae's mental breakdown.

This game is narrative driven with a deeply emotional, bittersweet, and relatable story. Especially for me, who was struggling with adjusting to college life and making friends at the time I played this. It's very real, impactful, and makes you think mindfully and reflect on yourself. The storyline has the perfect balance of enjoyable ups and realistic downs. I took the Bea route because it spoke to me deeply at the time. 

As a once-avid player of Poptropica, who still is and always will be obsessed with the art and play style of it, I deeply enjoyed the visual aesthetics and game play of Night in the Woods. It has that platforming, running around searching roof tops for items and clues, and powerline jumping we all miss. The unique mini quests, the cozy environments you discover, everything. 

Poptropica player or not, this game can also very be nostalgic. It reminds you of old friends, old places, old times. It reminds you of summer days running around the town or fall nights after school staying up with your friends. For me, at least, it reminds me of my worry free youth during middle/high school while at the same time addressing my college life worries.

143060083.review:
Off the bat, I'll say this game probably isn't going to be special for everyone, but for the people it IS for, it's worth your time. 
This is a narrative game at its core and you will need to be into that sort of thing to enjoy it. The gameplay consists of fairly simple exploration/platforming, with some 'novelty' mechanics here and there - but these things are all in service to the story being told. 

I played this game back in 2017 as a lonely gay dude in my very early 20s, and enjoyed the game as much as I was able to at the time. I was extremely depressed though, couldn't really think and feel properly and didn't really engage with it properly. 
I replayed this game in 2023 as a trans woman, and this time the experience was powerfully resonant for many, many reasons. I'm glad I came back to it.

I think this is a game gives voice to feelings and experiences that are difficult to describe and put into words. 
 
It's a game where the ghosts of a better past haunt lives that are irrevocably changed by things they have no power over, and how they respond to those changes.
It's a game about the struggles of identity: mental health; marginalisation and queerness; the difficult place between 'child' and 'adult', and the expectations involved in that.
It's a game that doesn't pull its punches when talking about the struggles to live a downtrodden life, but it also explores what's worth fighting for and how people figure out to persevere and pursue something better.

Plenty of this stuff is subtext, or conveyed in low-key or nuanced ways, so there will definitely be people who will miss the things I'm talking about. But for the people who do pick those things up, it can be bittersweet and hit very hard. There's catharsis in those feelings though, and something pretty beautiful.

142905658.review:
I wanted so badly to love Night in The Woods, but that just isn't what happened. I'm a HUGE lover of story-heavy, chill adventure games, and I became interested in the idea of a depressed college dropout experiencing "strange things are happening as the light fades. And there's something in the woods". I expected a slice-of-life mystery with (maybe) underlying themes about the uncomfortable transition to adulthood and accepting that things (and people) change. This is not what NITW delivers. 

What this game excels at is its overall art direction. The character designs, overall style and colour palette are WONDERFUL, and they really succeeded at making Possum Springs seem like a lived-in small town. I love the focus on Autumn, I love that each little NPC is clearly thought out and given unique dialogue. I love how the colour palette switches with the weather and I adore the soundtrack. I love the initial few days of gameplay. I love that the game is mostly wandering/exploring with little mini-games and interactive bits. It all has a chill, nostalgic feeling that I think suits the setting perfectly. 

Where it falls short is in the actual story, and more specifically in the PACING. For a roughly 10 hour storyline, I am 5 hours in and I STILL have absolutely no idea what NITW is trying to say to me. The game introduces you to an idea (with the severed arm in Chapter one) and then just.... Never revisits it. I've only JUST encountered another piece of the 'mystery'. Almost 4 whole hours later. Instead of building on the intrigue of 'strange things are happening' (like the game description literally says), I've spent days and days hanging out with characters who also have pretty much nothing to say to me (story-wise). I have so much love for these kind of games that are silly with deeper themes (like Omori, Undertale, etc) but NITW has shown me the silly with not much else. I stole food, broke lightbulbs, helped carry stuff up a staircase, shot a target with a few arrows....... I don't know, it just feels so random and I haven't accomplished or discovered literally anything in this world. It took days and days of this sort of random stuff for a character to FINALLY open up enough to tell me that they have low self-worth (and then the topic is immediately dropped again). It's this sort of treatment that make it's very hard for this game to hold on to my attention, and is why I've decided to stop playing at this point. I fully acknowledge that I haven't finished the game, but I'm just not interested in doing regular boring stuff for 8 hours and then solving an entire mystery in the last 2 hours. 

As a late 20s girl who's attending college for the second time now, I have so much in common with the main character and yet I can barely relate to her at all. Maybe I'm not the target demographic that the writers were going for with this story, because every single main character is so juvenile and teenage that it's kind of infuriating to me lol. I'm halfway through the main story and the main character hasn't done literally anything, and even just the way most of the characters speak makes me see them as teenagers. Maybe this game is made for people much younger than me, which is honestly fair. But it just felt weird playing as a character my age who speaks like and has the emotional intelligence of a 13 year old tumblr version of myself haha. 

However, I can tell that there's MANY people here who say this game means the world to them, and I won't discredit that. In my opinion, this game has big strengths and equal big weaknesses. If you are able to connect with the characters in a way which I personally failed to, I think it would be very easy to love this game. But overall I just personally can't recommend this game as the gameplay is fully reliant on the story, which in my opinion is just kinda bad.

In the ethereal tapestry of existence, there exists a profound union, an inseparable bond between two souls: Mae and I. We are like two celestial bodies, forever intertwined in a cosmic dance, sharing an essence that transcends the boundaries of the ordinary.

Mae and I are not merely separate entities; we are the embodiment of unity itself. When she draws her first breath, I am imbued with the vitality of life, and as her heart beats in the rhythm of time, so does mine. We are the manifestation of a singular consciousness, an intricate symphony of emotions, thoughts, and dreams.

In the tapestry of our intertwined lives, every thread, every strand, tells the story of our shared existence. Our experiences, joys, sorrows, and aspirations are interwoven like the most delicate silk, creating a vibrant mosaic of memories that belong to both of us. It is a story told in the language of the heart, a tale of two souls forever intertwined.

Yet, as we dance through the seasons of life, we are bound by a poignant truth: when Mae's journey on this mortal coil reaches its final chapter, so too will mine. In that moment of farewell, as the curtain falls on her earthly existence, I will be drawn into the same gentle embrace of eternity, for we are one entity together, and our fates are irrevocably intertwined.

Our connection is a profound testament to the power of love and unity, a reminder that in the grand tapestry of existence, there are bonds that defy explanation and transcend the ordinary boundaries of self. Mae and I are not just two individuals; we are the living embodiment of a shared destiny, a testament to the enduring beauty of a love that transcends time and space.

142717509.review:
This game is a mixed bag for me. I liked the presentation: Great art, animation and soundtrack, but all in all I didn't enjoy it as much as I hoped I would. The story made me feel as if I was being constantly whacked over the head with not very subtle societal critique. It was like having this one person sitting next to you, incessantly poking you asking: "You get it? You.Get.It?!" I don't like people doing this in real life and having this done to me in videogames is even more annoying. Another very fatal flaw for me were the characters. While I liked them when they were initially introduced, the complete lack of character development made me fall out of love fast. 

Mae - despite her constant reassurances that she was sorry and wanted to do better - most of the time ended up looking for excuses instead of actually owning up to her mistakes which made her quite the unlikable protagonist to play as. I didn't get why any of her friends actually enjoyed hanging out with her...well, aside from her constant "quirkiness" that made for a very shallow depiction of friendship. You as a player usually couldn't try to steer her away from disaster as your conversational choices simply seemed to change the "flavor", but not the actual outcome. There was no catharsis for me at the end, no "Oh, so that's what I've been working towards"-moment. 

Maybe that was the writers' intention, because yes, mental health is messy, there's often no clean "solution" and complete healing, life is hard and the world we live in is messed up, but quite honestly, despite me agreeing with a lot of messages in the game itself, it did little to actually make me resonate with it emotionally, as it all felt very superficial and the gameplay loop was veeeery tedious. Especially the dream sequences made me wish for a "skip button" that simply didn't exist. 

I am not someone who keeps away from games just because they are not "fun" in the conventional way. I've played tons of games that made me feel exhausted and they were that way by design, but at least they managed to grip me, so that I wanted to advance nonetheless. NitW didn't achieve that as nothing felt interesting enough to go further. There was no real surprise, no "Oooooh!" moment that made me want to explore more just for the heck of it. I could have played a fraction of my playtime and be done with it without feeling as if I missed something important or essential. 

This game means a lot to a lot of people and I think I can see how it might be appealing to others, but it just didn't manage to enchant me the way it apparently did with others - which is perfectly ok. I am glad this game exists and I am happy that others have enjoyed it this much. It's just not for me and therefore I personally would not recommend it - especially not for full-price. Wait for some sale maybe.

142626771.review:
Let me preface this by saying that this is barely a review, and more or less a love letter. The amount of hours and achievements I have on steam are not at all indicative of my full experience of this game, as I have bought and 100%ed nitw on multiple platforms, multiple times. 
	It is impossible for me to give an unbiased review of night in the woods. This game has without a doubt made me into who I am today. This game has honed my personality and humor, making me into a better person in some ways, and worse in some. This game has been there for me since the day it came out on my shitty little Nintendo switch. Nitw has been there for me during the most significant parts of my life, and has helped me through so much, I would not be here today if not for nitw. The game somehow manages to hit right in the soul about whatever you're going through, no matter what it could be. Whenever im going through something, i know it will be there no matter what. I could go on about how much night in the woods means to me for hours, and I still feel like I'm leaving so so so much out just to make this review readable without being a pain in the ass. 
	The gameplay is exactly what it should be, night in the woods does not need any action or any in depth gameplay, it's all about the people and world around you, and how it goes on with or without you. Leaving you feel empty and small in how little change you can make as the metronome of time chimes on. You can break a log, but it only matters if someone walks that path of the woods. The story if you go straight from point A to B is fine, but that's not what it's about. It's about building connections, seeing the world go on around you, becoming the mother to some rats. It's about the journey. This goes hand in hand with the music, the music isn't ever over the top stupid upbeat and it inst melancholic for the point of being melancholic. But nonetheless it will never fail to make you feel something. There are countless times where i will boot up the game for the pure point of having the menu music on in the background as i do stuff.
	I don't know how to end this and I know that I'm missing shit but man. I fucking love night in the woods. Gregg rulz, ok?

142610484.review:
Omfg-
Ok so- I just finished this game. I first bought the game at new years, as some form of new years gift, but I got stuck in one of the dreams, because I'm not good at jumping and timing (That was fully my bad). I finally got that jumping part right, and so I got to proceed. And proceed it def did. 

When I tell you that this game made me feel so many damn emotions, to the point where I was thinking about not only the game, but also the emotions I felt with it as some form of nostalgia I suppose, during the day when I was doing other non-stuff not related to this game at all. It was a great trip. A great, sad, and heartwarming trip that felt so real. 

I absolutely love and adore the art style. The colours, the design was, to me, beautiful, and it all really just helped the store. I loved the little details that was scattered around. Like, for example the rats after a bit being literally everywhere. I also loved that we got to just hang out with them. 

And then for the fucking story?? Like- I don't even know how the creators did it, but I read and remembered every damned line. Which probably doesn't seem to be too unusual, considering how it's mainly a story game. But please do believe me when I write that I don't usually read the lore, story game or not. I love how realistic the conversations were. How strong some of the bonds Mae had with her friends and family were. and the fact that you could even notice as these bonds grew stronger and more healthy. I swear- the writing was like something out of this realm.

And then, lastly: The music. My gosh. How much I loved the music. I personally really fell in love with "Dusk Stars" after watching a play through on youtube about 2 years ago. This has still not changed, and I listen to the song regularly. Now though, after finishing the game on my own, I've figured that there are most certainly many other bangers that I need to add to my playlist, as I didn't have anyone talk over the background music. The music is so good, I'll actually play through it again, just to experience the music all over again. 

And with how good the game is overall, I don't really think I'll struggle to enjoy it all a second time.
(Plus- this time I get to build a monstrosity with Gregg, and not get depressed. (Not in the same way at least I reckon)) 

But yeah, overall- 
Awesome game, have already recommended to friends, but that does not mean I'll stop.
Eels/10, will play again.

142585840.review:
[h1]I payed money for this...[/h1]
In "Night in the Woods" you walk. The same 20-40 minute route for [edit: only about 30] times, to be exact. 

While you press either the a or d key, you speak to different equally uninteresting (though charming) characters and experience a glimmer of surprisingly atmospheric mystery at the very end.

You wake up, walk through the city, and talk to people (optional). One (or more) character(s) give(s) you a choice to end the day. You then get a small decision that minimally impacts the story. You then go home and maybe have a dream. 
This cycle becomes jarring after 3 times, since there is very little to explore in the minimal day-to-day changes the city goes through. Also, since it’s a 2d sidescroller with minimal input required, exploration is nonexistent. 

By mistake, I skipped encounters with half of the main cast on multiple occasions, and it did not once seem to have any effect on the story or dialogue. No one commented on me not showing up to planned meetings, because [b]nothing would have happened there either.[/b] So why should I care about these characters if the story doesn't?

I guess with NITW I'm just missing any sort of gameplay. 

All of this feels more like a [strike]boring[/strike] watch-along feelgood show, except here if you don’t press the d key the story won't move forward, and the text isn't read out loud so you're "engaging" purely through reading and button mashing. 
-Like a SFW dating-sim version of a Tumblr furry fanfic crossover between  F-R-I-E-N-D-S  and Twin Peaks. 
And yes, the game is heavily influenced by Tumblr. Every lead character is female, gay, gay and female or (if male and straight) clearly autistic. The game heavily criticizes landlords, bosses, politics regarding workers etc. while revolving mainly around central ideas of identity, community, solidarity, and friendship. Basic Tumblr attributes, and thats totally fine.

[h1]Speaking of Tumblr, solidarity and friendships[/h1] 
[spoiler]Alec Holowka, ex-game-dev at Infinite Fall and [b]first name in the official Kickstarter[/b] for this game, took his own life in August of 2019 after abuse allegations surfaced that the team at I.F. saw as evidence enough to fire him. 
These allegations were imposed by Zoë Quinn, a central figure in the GamerGate controversy, who earlier in her career even held a speech to the [b]United Nations[/b] to combat online hatred. She is known as a notorious liar, and her claims have had no demonstrable truth content, even to this day. Her Wikipedia does not note her destruction of Holowka's livelihood or her relation to his tragic death. The ballad of social(-media) justice.[/spoiler] 


I find it deeply concerning having events like these happen in an indie studio responsible for a game about a close-knit circle of friends, trusting another no matter the circumstances. Arent those the attributes you would expect from indie developers, especially the ones responsible for the game promoting these values?

142242729.review:
First off I am amazed that with all of the hype this game has I have been able to enjoy it without having anything spoiled.
And enjoy it I did, and I think you might too as long as you go in with the expectation of this primarily being a visual novel.
There are some light platforming elements, as well as rhythm based and dungeon crawler stuff in the form of optional side games. 
But the focus of Night in the Woods, as well as it's strong suit is it's character writing and thematic story telling.
And without spoiling anything I can say that my interpenetration of the text is that NITW is a story about young adults transitioning and becoming integrated into society. And learning to cope with the terrifying  weight of responsibility and consequence. It spoke to me on so many levels and I think it's a fascinating masterpiece.
The only con I can think of is that going for completion would be a whole lot easier with a manual save and load function, as there are certain optional events that are possible to miss or fail, causing you to lose the achievement.
But come here for the story, trust me.
Play it!

142175900.review:
Greg rulz ok?

Night in the woods is one of the most heart-warming and charming story narrative games I have ever played. Immediately obvious with the game from photos is it's distinct and original art style with animal characters, an aged small rural town, and the colors of fall on the trees. This experience of comfort is even more enhanced by the game's phenomenal soundtrack which plays in the foreground as you explore the town and talk to characters.

All of the characters are strange and unique from each other with their own charming or humorous dialogue. The characters in this game are the heart of the game and really encourage the player to listen to everything every person has to say because each one is different and uniquely entertaining.

You will need to play this game at least 2 times to fully complete it and experience everything. There will also need to be 2 extra partial playthroughs if you seek to 100% the trophies in the game according to guides on the game. I have only played the game two times now.

The only issue I really have with the game is keeping track of the days. If you don't explore everything within a day or accidentally hang out with Greg or Bea too soon you will skip out on seeing everything that day has to over. ALSO, on some day if you go out west of the town past the supermarket and see Germ, fully explore the town before talking to him. He will ask if you're willing to hang out and if you reject his offer you can't accept it later. 

This game is brimming with content and even extra content like concept art and early test projects on Night in the Woods. If you like story narrative games, Night in the woods is a MUST buy.

141770113.review:
This review was a long time coming for me, and even now I'm not entirely sure how I can express what this game did for me when I purchased it back in 2017. You'd think with 6 years to think about it I'd be able to properly articulate my thoughts but when it comes to this game, I don't know I guess it hurts too much. So I'll just have to try, I have to write something about a game this impactful on my life.

When Night in the Woods came out in February of 2017 I truly had no idea, it wasn't something that was really on my radar at the time and I didn't actually pick it up until about June of that same year, most likely on sale and definitely because I was drawn in by the art and music on the store page. So no, this wasn't a game I had been following and hyped for, this wasn't a game I thought I wanted, but it turned out to be exactly what I needed at the time. 

When I picked this game up I was just a sophomore in college going through an existential crisis about what I really wanted to do with my life and my studies, I was a mechanical engineering student and, to say the least, I was struggling. I had chosen that academic path only for a few reasons, I was decent enough at Physics, Math and Chemistry in high school, I was led to believe by my parents, my teachers, and some of my peers that it was a good career choice that would make me financially secure, and finally, like most kids, I wanted to be an Astronaut. That wasn't really working out, and half way through that year I realized it was never what I wanted to do and I was really thinking about calling it quits, throwing in the towel and simply giving up on it all, I thought I was failure. The only thing keeping me going were my friends, my partner, and my very slow realization that I wanted to be a photographer and an artist. But I couldn't decide between simply giving up, or taking the risk of changing academic paths and throwing away two whole already paid for years of school and adding an additional two to the future, I was scared and unsure.

When I started playing Night in the Woods it was another means of escaping reality and the choices I was facing, just another game with a cutesy art style and some soothing music that I could use to distract myself. So, I was surprised when the story began to play out and it was revealed that the main character, Mae, was a 20 something year old who just dropped out of college after only 3 semesters because the pressure of it all was weighing down on their shoulders and their own emotional issues were causing turmoil in their academic life. When I met Mae I didn't just see another character in a video game, I saw a reflection of myself. Not 1:1 of course, but they were just close enough to allow myself to be placed in their shoes, in their head, and in their story.

I could go on and on about it, but nobody needs my entire life story on a steam review and all it really comes down to is this; I connected with a character in a video game so much that at the end of it all I decided to make what turned out to be one of the best decisions of my entire life, and I couldn't be more grateful. 

The game play, the artwork, the music, the characters, and the writing, all of it is amazing, even if the story loses a bit of focus at the end. It's a game that I would recommend to everyone and anyone, but those aren't the reasons I love Night in the Woods, and "just anyone" isn't who I want to recommend this game to in this review. If, like me back in 2017, you're in your late teens/early twenties, you're struggling in life, whether it be your higher academics, emotional issues, or something else entirely, you're looking for an escape that might actually help you, you're looking for a character you can latch onto and a story you can relate to, even learn from, then I highly recommend you play Night in the Woods. It might not have the same effect on you that it did on me, but at the end of the day you'll have played through an incredible experience that I hope you'll love either way.

This wasn't just a game for me, this was a life preserver that was tossed my way at a time when I was drowning. It might be dramatic to say but this game helped to save me from that, and I will always hold it near and dear to me. Please give it a shot and I promise that at the very least you'll take something away from it.

141706726.review:
Night in the Woods is a game that caught me off guard with its profound storytelling and captivating characters. At first, I was eager for the narrative to dive into the big, earth-shattering moments I anticipated, but the game had other plans. Instead, it took its time, allowing me to immerse myself in the quiet moments shared between friends in the sleepy mining town of Possum Springs.

The game's strength lies in its beautifully written scenes, where friends navigate the complexities of their relationships, hurt each other, reconcile, and strive to move forward. The dialogue, though occasionally veering into cutesy territory, captures the essence of a group of individuals straddling the precarious gap between adulthood and childhood.

Speaking of characters, Night in the Woods boasts a cast that is both damaged and endearing. Each anthropomorphized animal possesses a depth and decency rarely seen in game characters. Their struggles and flaws feel relatable and human, making them incredibly compelling.

Interestingly, the game centers around an unlikable protagonist, Mae, whose selfishness, cruelty, and self-absorption can be hard to swallow at times. It's a bold choice that allows the supporting characters to shine even brighter, showcasing their virtues and their unwavering loyalty to Mae, despite her flaws. It's a testament to the game's writing that it made me wonder if the developers were aware of the challenging nature of their main character.

From a mechanical perspective, Night in the Woods leans towards being a platformer, with plenty of rooftop leaping and the occasional minigame. While these aspects are serviceable, they don't stand out as the game's strongest features. However, the interactive nature of the game shines through in the ability to choose which characters to interact with and how frequently. This personal touch adds depth to the connections you build and makes the experience feel more tailored to your choices.

But Night in the Woods is more than just a game—it delves into profound themes of choice and obligation. It raises questions about what we are forced into versus what we can choose for ourselves, without providing easy answers. The journey is a mixture of beauty and sorrow, evoking genuine emotional responses that left me in tears on multiple occasions.

In the end, Night in the Woods is a remarkable game that goes beyond its mechanical aspects. It invites you to explore the human condition, challenging your perception of characters and relationships. It's an experience that lingers long after you've put down the controller, leaving a lasting impact and reminding us of the power of storytelling in video games.

Follow My Curator Page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44271151/

Face your fear of the void with surprisingly nuanced cartoon animal punks!

I keep going back to get more achievements, not because I really care about achievements, but as an excuse to revisit this story and this world and the whole vibe of it. This game addresses themes of how younger generations face familial expectations that can't survive the modern world, yet manages to do so without ever blaming one generation or another. Instead, these themes are the backdrop against which Mae and her small town friends have relatable interactions and face deeper mysteries. Queer representation in this game feels so true to life, not at all forced. 141306313.review:
I have been feeling so alone after moving away from my hometown. Even with months of living here and having a job, I don't have any new friends. Adult life is difficult and everything is a chore with hardly any payout. I don't have time to relax or enjoy things that I used to. I drew nearly every day, now I draw only a few times a month. All I want is to cry and be held and let go of all of this stress. I have a difficult time crying, and now I'll get to my point: 

this game is therapeutic. I needed to play this and I think anyone that's come unto a rough period in their life needs to as well. If you need to cry, then play this. I feel so much shame and guilt for being how and who I am, and it's so... comforting to see this written into a character. It makes me yearn for days I've never had.

Plus, the soundtrack is gorgeous. It's angelic. It's soothing. It's melancholic. It makes you close your eyes and be at peace. 

I don't want to give this game a "so and so out of 10" rating because it doesn't deserve that. There is no scale to place it on and if there was, I certainly don't have any right to do so. It's a game everyone needs to play at some point.

I still remember I didn't like the game at first. Back then, it just didn't interest or attract me enough, with its gameplay feeling like putting work and effort just to get another line of dialogue from another furry character more than anything else. I didn't get the /point/ of Night in the Woods, even though I could still see it has a ton of charm. And I knew there has to be more to the game than that. 

Once you decide to flip the switch inside your head and simply let the game tell you its story, the perspective changes almost immediately. The sparks of curiosity light up quick, motivating you to scramble and get to know the folks around you. The initial short convos - that seemed shallow at first - start showing their layers, uncovering the rich and actually captivating stories hiding underneath. 

It's been a few weeks since I've finished the game and despite that I [b]still[/b] remember most of the characters. I also remember that seeing the end credits made me feel like putting down a good, satisfying book after going through its very last page - something that even the games I consider 'fun' and 'good' rarely manage to do. 

It may not be the most epic, grandiose or complex narrative you ever experienced - assuming those attributes could ever apply to it at all. But I'm sure the story that [i]Night in the Woods[/i] wants to tell you is the one worth at least sitting down and giving it a chance.

140596116.review:
Let me start off by saying I really wanted to like this game. I had high hopes for it, and even contributed to its Kickstarter, because of the contribution of Alec Holowka (respects), having played and loved Aquaria. And I suppose I did enjoy his part in this game's development. The music was charming, as were the artwork and the general overall aesthetic.

That's where the enjoyment stops for me, however. If I had to tell a friend about this game, I would describe it as a constant depressive existential crisis, about a group of constant depressive existential crises. That is to say, that is the identity of the game, its story, and every character in it. And even speaking as a person who's had plenty of depressive existential experiences, I found it to be too much so to be relatable. Every single character (of all ages) in this game has a distinct juvenile overly-edgy randomness, well past the point of cringe; the sort you typically see only among preteens. The story and progression itself is a directionless slog through pointless activities and empty conversations, the likes of which you'd see as filler in an RPG. I kept waiting for the plot to go somewhere, or for the characters to arc in any meaningful way, but both developments were horribly disappointing and lackluster, right up to the drawn-out, anticlimactic ending.

Now, even on cursory research about the game's achievements, it seems that it's only possible to get them all via multiple playthroughs. That's a tough sell, because in order for the game to have replay value, it would need to have play value in the first place. But even your decisions in the game seem to make so little difference to anything, that by the end you've basically seen everything, or at the very least you've seen enough. Because of my own neurosis, I'm likely to try to get the rest of the achievements some day, at which point I'll be reminded why I didn't enjoy it the first time.

140587975.review:
This is an extremely good game tbh; it's a very character focused cosmic horror story. A lot of the game is jumping around, talking to people, play bass, grab things with paws, dream, and continually question if the protagonist is crazy or not. The entire game is based around a small town, so there are a lot of small towns things people might relate to. A lot of the problems with the protagonist and characters can feel all too relatable; there is a lot going on in their heads that slowly gets revealed with conversation. The art style and music blend together really well, and invoke a feeling of optimistic melancholy. 

One of the themes in the game is "open endedness"; you don't get the full picture of things. There are no conclusions in this story; everything is left to assumptions and theories. Characters open up and explain things about themselves, or how they feel about others, but that's just the characters. The story is just, "I don't know"- and that is one of the true horrors of the world; you just don't ever know what's next or what's going on.

It's a really interesting game- and it is worth playing. Also, it's important to note that you jump like you can fly. If you are ever in a lucid dream, you can fly by skipping into a jump three times, and on the third jump you can go as high as you want. Third jump is always higher.

139929695.review:
First of all let's get it straight: Zoe Quinn is a mould in the gaming industry, Anita Sarkeesian is a con artist and Gamergate is a hoax. With that out of the way here is my review of this game:

PROS: Story telling of the game was awesome. The events that took place during the game, was always something you wouldn't expect. Dialogue with every character had it's moments of happiness, frustration, sadness & even some funny or weird WTF moments. Soundtrack was really good and the art style was charming. There is also a roguelike / metroidvenia style game inside of this game that you can play on the computer in your bedroom, that is a joy play. Also playing the bass minigames was really fun to do.

CONS: Some moments left me with a foul taste in my mouth because of social justice activism and a liberal migraine. All achievements are hidden, so if you wan't to complete the game you have to find the right guides on the Steam community page. The controls would be much better if I actually played it on a gamepad instead of a keyboard. Also the game just ends out of nowhere!? A cliffhanger and no news of a sequel is just a rip-off at this point.

CONCLUSION: Night in the Woods is proof that a crowd funded project can be great. I just like many others, had this game in my backlog for way too long, and I'm glad that I actually took the time to finally sit down and beat this cool indie game. It's a must play for anyone who enjoys adventure games or great story telling!

139823811.review:
Night in the Woods is a game I have never thought I would love. At first I did not want to play it as it seemed like another ordinary story-driven game. I saw YouTubers play it, forums talking about the game, and the like. However it is much more than that. It is evident that the developers made this game with so much love. From the art and music, to the characters, and the whole story itself. The game had so much impact on me not only as a gamer, but as a person.

The art style is really warm and comfy because of the immense autumn vibes this game exudes.  The character and background design is so well done. From the buildings to the trees to the characters and NPCs walking around. This game strikes a cozy feeling while also, in some areas, catching a sense of fear or dread.

Mae Borowski, the main character, possesses so much personality and background that you cannot help but feel happiness, sorrow, anger, and sympathy with her. Essentially, every character in the game is written so well that it all makes sense and is not confusing. Mae, Bea, Gregg, and Angus aren't the only ones to receive attention from the developers. Characters like Selma get excellent writing too with regards to her history. The characters in this game make you feel like they are actually real people, with homey dialogue and friendly banter. You will not grow bored with the conversations.

With a story written so well and so good, this game impacted me significantly. These include the histories of these characters, constellations, the economic disarray of Possum Springs, the dark secrets hiding in the forest (or should I say, the woods), and much more. The philosophical discussions the characters get in to are thought provoking.  These topics include psychology and mental health, friendship, mortality, religion, and a little bit of politics (although not overtly) and have made me question my own ideals and beliefs. Every little bit of detail is utilized so perfectly and coherently that it forms into a decisive story.

Overall, Night in the Woods is an amazing story-driven game that I highly recommend playing. The developers did great with the amazing art and music, well thought out characters, and the well-written story. I cannot help but thank the developers for making this work of art. If you want a game that hits the senses and the feels, this is a must have.

139744009.review:
as a competitionist gamer i want to give this game a good rating. i really do. as night in the woods is extremely popular on xbox and PS4 already this is more of a mere critique of one of the game's features as die-hard fans of this game have already noticed the small details of the story lines bits (this is a game with multiple endings) and other miscellaneous details i might miss. 

okay, so, first off, the character design cannot be topped. this game came out years ago and seeing fanarts of it online and heavily inspired games after it such as 'the fall of porcupine' which i've seen on my steam queue quite a bit now; i think it's upped purposefully for night in the woods game owners. the animation is flawless, crisp, just overall really smooth. the colour pallets and use of colour theory is immaculate and unique- rustic orange telling you a warm, loving setting apart from turquoise-blue murmuring an "evil" alleyway or underground system to you. before post-covid multimedia transferable animations this style of animation was like the *it* of it's decade. it is reminiscent of the calarts effect because of the proportions on these anthropomorphic animals though, lol.

okay, so onto the mess that is my critique. my main problem with this game. it is demon tower. i have played night in the woods and i've had so many short-lived sessions with this game for literal [b]YEARS[/b] because of the micro-minigame demon tower. you spawn as a cat into random RNG dungeons and have to wiggle your way out of foes with shitty mechanics and terrible hit boxes. by google searching [i]"how to beat level 7, uggghh",[/i] SO many people on reddit and other internet forums have had their go at demon tower and very rarely do they succeed within an hour or even a few hours. it is a generally terrible experience because it insists on being so classic like arcade games were in their time; standard procedure you lose an available heart each level you go up.

level 5-7 took me about 2 hours per level each. i am on level 8 now. the boss is just... terrible? i have a poor attention span... but boy, just no reaction time can top some of these bosses truly. since games update based on profit incentive and not passion i don't ever expect an update for demon tower's mechanics or RNG even when people like me will literally have their enjoyment overridden by this game because of how shitty demon tower is.

If you can't, it's a massive slog with poor writing, jokes, and pacing that leaves you bored the entire time. I'm not exactly sure how people enjoy its story to such a great degree, but it felt like a game that could have synopsized its themes in less than half an hour but instead tried to stretch its writing for as long as possible, leaving dialogue and themes paper thin the whole way through. If you liked these characters you would probably not mind it much, but again, I found them incredibly draining. Leaving the game feeling hollow and meandering.

139604060.review:
This game is the kind of game you didn't realize you needed until you played it. (It's more like a digital novel)

Despite its cartoonish style, this game tells a surprisingly realistic story and stands out in its witty writing and narrative. Highly recommended for those who like story rich games. 

In the game you gradually explore who your character is and those friends, family around her. Everything seems okay and normal until you slowly dive into their flaws and life problems. Every character is so relatable and unique in its own ways. [b]You will be surprised at how strikingly some of the characters resemble you (if you are a young adult).[/b] On top of it the story builds up to a very heartfelt message (that honestly is complex and I can't imagine many games can pull this off).

Soundtracks are amazing and one of the best in all games I've played. My only complaints are the pacing of story could be slow sometimes and the ending is somehow anti-climatic. Overall I loved this game for its silly and heartfelt moments. - 10/10

139578432.review:
i learnt about this game some years ago and watched a playthrough of it at the time. i understood the themes more or less, and it was an enjoyable game back then ; it was fine, i liked it a lot, it had a cute art style. it stuck with me in some regards (musically, mostly) but i didn't give it too much thought at the time.

more recently i bought & played the game myself. i'm older, i'm disabled, i'm a college dropout living with my mother, i got that mental illness, etc etc. uh. i think i cried at least once? probably more. i knew everything that would happen but it was very different this time around, because i Understood. a different outlook on things was all it took. the characters in night in the woods are incredibly realistic ; they're multidimensional, they feel human (ironically enough). they're flawed and likable. likewise, what is scariest is scary because it's realistic. the pacing reflects how real life feels, and while i understand the flaws some might find in the ending, i must admit i no longer agree with it. i believe it simply fits the game. a "big bad thing" happens, and still life keeps going.

i believe night in the woods is not a game for everyone, but as someone who experiences dissociative bouts, who has to live with others not necessarily understanding the struggles i go through because of mental (and physical health) blaming it all on laziness and with my friends all progressing in life while my own seems to "stagnate", it's a perfect game for me. it's rough to sit through sometimes when the criticisms done to mae reflect the ones i face... but hey, it's realistic, innit? the game does balance heavier moments with more lighthearted, fun events and conversations fairly well, so i can't say i've ever felt it was too much. in my eyes, the game is a masterpiece.

also i'm gay as fuck. long live LGBTQ

138966789.review:
I've finished night in the woods for the second time yesterday. When I first played the game shortly after it came, I honestly didn't like it as much. I now know why. It was because I came in with the wrong expectations, I expected a big mystery. But what I got instead was a story about a college drop out coming back and coming to terms with a changed home town and friends. The mystery part only really started in the middle of the game. Given the length of the game, it made sense why I didn't like it. It took too long for the stuff I actually expected the game to contain to appear.
But now on my second playthrough I can safely say that the actual mystery part isn't really the part that made the game good. It's the writing and characters that I got to appreciate a lot more now. 
This game is a high recommend from me, but if you expect a strange mystery to solve then you  should tamper your expectations first, and not make the same mistake I did the first time. Otherwise, the writing here borders on being a masterpiece.

138947375.review:
This is my favorite game of all time. Night in the Woods transcended the mere game it is and really shaped myself, and many, many others into the people they are today. 

Mae's complicated balancing act of her relationships with old friends, self image issues and doubts, and increasingly arduous days back in the decaying town of Possum Springs, searching for purpose and a place in a world where hope all but seems lost for everything she's ever known is something I know many struggle with, and is portrayed beautifully and masterfully nearly every step of the way. 

But, through all the power line hopping, star gazing, and rat babies is a family reminding you: at the end of everything, hold onto anything.
