138449574.review:
"Night in the Woods" is a stylish, narrative focused game which follows the story of Mae Borowski, a cat and a college dropout, returning to her home town for some time out.

The game's main selling point is it's colourful cast of characters; Mae's family, old friends, acquaintances and familiar strangers, you know, the usuals in your home town. Exploring our protagonist's long established relationships and all their facets is as rewarding as meeting new faces and getting to know them is fun! You're guaranteed to meet some personalities you can't help but grow attached to (Greg rulez!OK?).

As a plot driven game, the pacing serves perfectly. You truly get a sense of the days dragging on and yet seamlessly merging together, fittingly capturing that feeling of being stuck at home as an adult, not really sure where you're going. As for the story itself; it's a great vessel to learn more about the characters, really leaving you rooting for everyone! However, some of Mae's mental health struggles, on which the story pivots are incredibly specific and, I would hazard, alienating to many people. Moreover, the final third of the game is a bit rushed and arrives at an unsatisfying conclusion. That criticism aside there's still much there to be enjoyed.

The game is packaged beautifully, with consistent visual tones for all of it's scenes, accompanied by a sweet and memorable soundtrack and straightforward game-play which facilitates the steady flow of the narrative. As an animator myself, I really appreciated "Night in the Woods"' simple but adorable artstyle!

Night int the Woods is definitely worth playing. If you've ever felt stuck in life, I think you'll like it. Although the story is rushed near the ending, it's unforgettable characters, beautiful style and sountrack more than make up for it.

138173316.review:
After spending 12 hours playing this game I am sad to report that it did not click for me on an emotional or mechanical level at all. I do not like saying this because I don’t enjoy tearing games down and I was genuinely looking forward to playing this, but outside of the art direction, music and Demontower minigame, Night in the Woods did not appeal to me in the way I was hoping it would.

The story, for what little there is, is generally unfocused and lacking in any real urgency, drama or stakes for roughly 85% of the story. I understand that this is a slice-of-life, slowburn type of deal and I was not expecting the story to hook me immediately. The vibes for the first hour or so were pretty good, but as the game progressed I was hoping the story would naturally develop into something more interesting and I was left wanting until the last quarter of the game. I can only speak for myself of course, but eventually your story needs a hook and this story barely has even that for most of its runtime.

If the characters of Night in the Woods were more interesting and fascinating this glacial pacing could’ve been acceptable to me, unfortunately the characters do not fare much better either. I enjoyed talking to Gregg, Bea and Candy. The rest of the main and supporting cast were not very interesting or developed. I found Mae, the main character of the game to be a conflicting presence in the story. She is deeply troubled, lacking any real focus in her life, depressed and her general dissociation from the real world was initially compelling and I did see parts of myself in her character when I was younger. Sadly, as the game progressed her responses to her friends' issues rubbed me the wrong way and I found her to be increasingly less relatable as the game pushed forward. I didn’t dislike her presence in the story, but by the end of the game I was very indifferent to her overall.

The story touches on topics like paranormal activity, the cruel indifference of capitalism, mental illness, cults and the expectations of being an adult in a world that does not care for you.

Somehow, this game did not click for me despite it seeming tailor made for me based on these topics and yet I felt underwhelmed after completing it. Why is that? It’s hard to fully pin down in an easily digestible sentence, but I think the writing wasn’t interested in exploring these concepts in a way that was interesting.

At the very least, the game did not resonate with me in the same way it did for most other players. I initially assumed the slow start would eventually pay off. It did not. The ending was also fairly abrupt and I did not feel satisfied with its conclusion.

Here’s the thing though, most people who play this do genuinely see something special about it even if I personally did not. I do not even fully regret playing it, but I think I could’ve stopped playing it around the 3 or 4 hour mark and achieved the same level of satisfaction from it that I did after completing it. If you want an adventure game that is cute, has quirky dialogue and is running entirely on vibes, you will probably find NITW to be a good time. If you expect the game to be anything more than that, you might be a little disappointed with the overall experience.

Night in the Woods charmed me, spooked me, and got me thinking about lots of nihilistic feelings I've been having for a while. It's coincidentally one of those "right place, right time" games for me. But even without the timely playthrough, I would've enjoyed this story either way.

While there are some minigames that can be briefly "fun" shake-ups in the gameplay, most of the game is spent exploring the town and talking to all the townsfolk. I generally love walking sims, but I could see how some people would get tired of all the redundant exploration. At least the art is a joy to look at.

What also helps is the enjoyable dialogue. The characters and interactions are very cozy, friendly, and goofy. It evokes the same sort of feelings I got when I first finished Persona 4--feeling a strange, but warming, sort of connection to these unreal, digital people, and a sort of emptiness when it's all over. But the journey felt magical.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]

This is a story about the dark spots in your mind, about the bonds that tie a person to the ones around them, about what makes you "you". I discovered this game at a bit of a low point in my life, and played it through with one of my best friends. I have [b]many[/b] feelings and thoughts about it but I will not ramble too much. Suffice it to say, I cried a bit (a lot) at some points during the story.

The premise is already a heavy-hitter (no spoliers here, sorry), and the story only gets better as events progress. The well rounded soundtrack and sound work/ambient sounds (the bounce/step sounds are stellar!!!) immediately drag you into the setting. Platforming feels smooth and fun, and combined with the unique art-style it makes "just walking around to go talk to your neighbours and friends" really entertaining. The cozy style adds a nice contrast to the (gloomy at points) story, and the writing and developement of the characters make you forget that you are, in fact, talking to a 2-D animal drawing. Speaking of 2-D; the characters are anything but. Everything feels so alive, I do not know how else to describe it.

In short: a really interesting, emotional, delightful game. I highly recommend it.

Ok, real talk, how does this game have 94% positive reviews? Did I miss something or am I simply not getting it? For a game that scored this high I had equally high expectations, but with each hour spent in the game I gradually became more and more bored, the game is a walking simulator most of the time and that is one of the weakest parts of the game, each day you have to walk through the same location with the same slow walking speed. I get that the highlight of the game supposed to be the story, which also falls flat. From the start game throws at you a couple mysteries that are supposed to keep you engaged and try to figure out what's going on as the story progresses. The problem is that is the game fails to deliver any answers to your questions and just throws more plot points or give you like a half baked answer. 
[Spoilers ahead] We play as Mea, a 20 years old cat lady who's a collage dropout and has no idea what to do in her life, which I guess was ment to be relatable to people in a simular situation, but the relatability end's here. Seriously, how does people find her appealing? Her demeanor is of a child, who has no self awareness and plays the know-it-all at times, moreover she has like no character development, she never learns from her behavior and stays the same through the plot, besides maybe getting more spiritual/depressed or whatever those dreams ment to be. Halfway through the game some hooded mofo appears, who kiddnaps some guy and runs of, later you learn there's a whole cult of them in the old cave and they're on a mission to change the world by killing people by pushing them in the hole or some sheet (I might have made some of that up) and then they disappear never to be seen again and game ends... What is the point, what is the message of the game, because that's what is important here, nothing made sense at the end, no message to take from the game. Like what business did Mea even had in that whole investigation thingy? Her dreams were connected to that cult or something, cause she heard some voices that tried to gave her an existential crisis??
As you can see I understand jack sheet from the game, personally I don't recommend the game at all, I think it was boring and the story as well as the characters (Mea in particular) are bad that don't hold any meaning, at least that's what from my experience. If you're kind enough, please do prove me wrong in the comments why the game and the story is actually great and the message it tries to push, because that is a part of why story driven games are great.

136035721.review:
The Steam review system isn't fitting for my thoughts on this game.

I don't know what I think about Night in the Woods. If I had to summarize, what it does good, it does pretty good. But in order to get to the good, there's a lot of tedium to go through, and the boredom of that tedium rubs off on the good of the game.

What I liked about this game is everything about the game except the game. Music and visuals and what have you are cute, but the soul of this game is its character writing and themes. Most of what works about Night in the Woods can be summarized by focusing on Mae. Mae is a fascinating character. She succeeds where Alex YIIK fails - she is a frustrating, immature asshole who I should hate, and yet I can’t, because I see too much of myself in her.

It’s hard for me to verbalize what makes her a great character, but it’s probably because she’s uncomfortably relatable. She wants to get better, but she doesn’t know how. The person she lies to the most is herself. She can’t bring herself to open up with those around her. She’s someone who, scared of growing up, chose to cope instead of moving on, despite everyone else moving beyond that point. And I know too well what all of that feels like.

Mae isn’t a good person, but it isn’t entirely her fault, either. What brought Mae to this point is a combination of her own mistakes and things out of her control, and the game’s exploration of what shaped her is where a lot of the themes come in. This game touches on many, many concepts - coming of age, mental illness, capitalism - and Mae has been shaped by these concepts in some way or another. Mae grapples with understanding these concepts herself, and the game takes a magnifying glass to her and the way she’s tangled in a complex web of themes in order to examine them with an insightful understanding of why they so deeply affect Mae and the world she lives in - and how Mae and the world respond to these themes in return. 

What I didn’t like about this game was the game. In a single word, it's slow. Slow can be good. I'm not a stranger to slow games. One of my favourite games of all time is a visual novel. But Night in the Woods is S. L. O. W. Slow. The bulk of the gameplay is slowly travelling across town, slowly enough and often enough that what starts off quaint becomes frustratingly tedious quickly. The little snippets of other gameplay during story beats are a change of pace, but ultimately too shallow to be particularly interesting. And those story beats sound with a strange narrative rhythm.

Night in the Woods spends a lot of its time as a slice of life with day to day interactions. And while I love slice of life and will argue that “a narrative doesn’t always need a story, just good characters”, Night in the Woods puts that argument to the test. Even though I adore the characters and the slices of their lives we see, with the sluggish gameplay filling the gaps between those interactions, what could have been a nice and sweet experience instead feels like a chore that drags on for too long, especially without a particularly sharp narrative hook for most of the game.

And when the game decides to attach its hook, it’s a strange, strange hook. It’s a hook that, despite feeding into the numerous themes and being hinted at throughout the game, still comes in out of left field. It’s an entertaining and thrilling hook, but a strange hook nonetheless. And once it hooks, the game immediately reels in at that instant, ending almost immediately after hooking, ending on an anti-climatic climax without resolve. Was this the intent? I think so. Is it unsatisfying regardless? I also think so.

In the end, I'm torn. While I liked my time with the game, the parts that I didn’t enjoy are what stuck with me. My overall feelings are mixed, and yet I still can’t tell if I liked this game or not. I would give this game a negative review, but Steam's review system is based on recommending or not recommending a game. And I do recommend this game.

I played this game at a very fitting time in my life, being in the exact same situation as the main character - a 20 year old college dropout struggling to find out what to do with their life, wanting to become a better person without knowing how. Playing this game was like staring at a mirror. Maybe it's for this reason I expected more from this game. As silly as it is, I wanted this game to give me answers. And to its credit, it did give answers. But I don’t know why I couldn’t take those answers. Maybe they’re answers I’ve already known, maybe they’re answers I didn’t know how to take, maybe they’re answers I refused to take, maybe I flat out missed an answer, maybe I didn’t understand those answers, maybe I just wasn’t ready for those answers. I don’t know.

This game is exactly the game I needed, one that was practically designed to resonate with me, and yet, it didn’t. Night in the Woods may not have fully resonated with me, but there's people out there that it will. And I hope this game reaches them.

I don’t know if I like this game. But I do recommend it.

135078410.review:
I remember you. It was early fall, 2020. I'd just been banned from my computer. I was browsing on my Xbox One with the game pass late at night, and what do I see? A cute little game with animal characters. I think, "Ah what the hell I'll try it." A cute ferret and a little flashing leaf leads me into a title screen with a cool song. I hit New Game.

Two days later I'm crying and feeling empty reading the credits because I'll never get to play you fresh for another time, and there will never be anything like you again.

You hit me in the feels. Right in that little core where all my doubts and fears and wonderment for the future were stored.

I realized, when it scrolled all the way down and I was given one last chance to read that little notebook of doodles: Life hurts. When I die, I want it to hurt. To mean something. Because if it does, it'll mean I made an impact on someone I loved and cared about. It'll mean my life wasn't some kind of cosmic waste of space designed to accelerate the heat death of the universe by an infinitesimal fraction. I have never, will never, be the same again, and I wouldn't have it any other way. Thank you for changing my life. 

Recquiescat in Pace.

134519449.review:
[h1]Maybe I just don’t get Night in the Woods.[/h1]
I’ve seen high praise for Night in the Woods nearly every time it’s brought up. I watch and read a lot of reviews for games to find out what to play. This game not only scores really well, but I often see it as a successful comparison for pulling off what another game tried to do. After hearing all of that, I still don’t get the praise. A lot of that could be linked back to the narrative not personally clicking with me, but even then there’s a bunch of little things that I’m not a fan of.

Night in the Woods is a walking simulator and I’ve made my opinions on those pretty clear in the past. Besides just walking around, you can choose who you hang out with while the main story progresses. There’s no real effect on the actual plot when you only hang out with different people. All it dictates is what scenes you’ll see. Unlike most walking sims though, this one has a little arcade game called Demontower and I’m really glad it exists. It’s a teensy little roguelike that I didn’t experiment with too much, but I like that the game actually has some gameplay in it past what dialogue you get dumped with. I overall think my enjoyment with NitW would be much higher if it was an animated short or film because of its minimal gameplay. It’s a very frequent trend where games that focus entirely on their story just give up when it comes to actually being a video game. It’s not like good writing and good gameplay are mutually exclusive; So why do we have to stop the interactivity at who you hang out with?

So that makes the story the major selling point. I play games with really bad writing all the time and while NitW isn’t anywhere near the level of some of the worst I’ve seen, that doesn’t make it really good. It’s mainly the characters and ending for me, but I’ll personally admit that I didn’t really relate to the main character and that seemed to be the main goal the story was trying to achieve. Mae as a whole is a really irritating character for me. She’s rude, brash, reckless, violent, and just kind of a dick. Some of her endeavors include mindless destruction and a game of stabbing each other with her friend. I know she’s meant to be a childish college dropout that doesn’t know what to do with her life, but I think most people in that situation at least try not to throw a temper tantrum over every little thing. Some of the side characters are just as guilty as this, with Bea being the only notable exception. I honestly don’t believe that Bea and Mae are friends at all though. As for the ending; It just sort of throws the entire plot at you and then just ends? Like a whole cult shows up responsible for most of the background plot and they just sorta disappear as quickly as they appeared. There are also the dream sequences which felt like they were put in to give the impression that the game is deep, but I’m willing to potentially chalk that up to me just not getting it. The story as a whole can be divided into parts that greatly irritated me, bored me, or confused me.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2042208284
The only thing I really like about the game is the art style. It’s got a very simplistic hand-drawn 2D look to it. I’ve never seen another game that looks like it. The best way I can compare it to is the generic corporate style you see in advertising but with a spray of actual humanity and identity applied to it. Probably not the best comparison, but I kind of like it overall. I’ve also heard a lot of really good things about the OST but again it’s just something that didn’t click with me. I’ve linked the most popular song below though.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2038550713
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O_yyu-kqfBs
Overall, I don’t really like Night in the Woods. [b]Maybe it’s just not for me or maybe I just don’t get it. I’m personally giving it a 4/10 but I think I would’ve enjoyed it way more if it wasn’t a game.[/b] If it was an animated short, show, or film I think I would’ve actually liked it way more. Might’ve prevented me from seeing some of the bits that really aggravated me in the first place as well. I know it’s very common to see tons of games that only care about developing their story, but I feel like too many of them don’t even come close to gripping with said story. Scream at me all you want for my opinion, but my review and my rules.

134268446.review:
“God Moves Things Around In The Strangest Ways To Bring Two People Together.”

NIGHT IN THE WOODS is an adventure game that is more of a walking simulator, similar to Kentucky Route 0, which is heavy on dialogue. The core of NITW is how it focuses on each character and fleshes them out. The game starts in a bus station with Mae Borowski returning to Possum Springs, her hometown, after dropping out of college. 

Admittedly, I was not a fan of Mae and preferred Bea, her childhood best friend, more as a character. I found Mae to be aimless, too negative, constantly making excuses, lacking self-awareness, and making sarcastic remarks during the first hours I played the game. Despite these issues, I have 27.3 hours of playtime recorded on Steam because of how much I immersed myself in the first playthrough.

The art, soundtrack, characters, atmosphere, and aesthetic of the game easily won me over, but what made me love it was how relatable and existential it got later on. I originally thought that it was going to be a cutesy-styled game that would be a coming-of-age story, but instead, it reminded me of themes from EEAAO. From ideas of this monstrous existence, choice, and freedom; the purpose of life; regret, pain, and missing out on experiences and opportunities; to the eventual existential crisis, I started to find Mae and other characters relatable. 

NITW constantly had me guessing what the meaning of it was since it combined the elements of a small nostalgic town with creepy cultists and a philosophical cosmic horror… sky cat? I enjoyed the minigames they had in them, especially Mae’s journal with doodles. 

Others may not like this game because it's a walking simulator or an interactive movie, but I think that video games shouldn’t be limited to FPS or horror. I think that if you are interested in philosophy or the arts, you should be willing to try it out in different mediums, like video games. Games like What Remains of Edith Finch, Scorn, Outerwilds, and even Disco Elysium (which I all love, btw) are great examples of video games with fantastic storytelling and dialogue. I was not kidding when I said that Annapurna Interactive is the equivalent of A24 Studios in gaming. Either way, I highly recommend this game to anyone into “interactive movies.”

Take note that this is a very surface-level review of the game annnnd that I bought it while on sale (around PHP 100)

134245596.review:
This game is a story game through and through. I was dragging my feet on playing it for a long time, and now that I have, I'm a little annoyed it took me this long. But in further explanation of my first sentence there, I don't want people to think this game is more than what it is, because otherwise, you might feel disappointed.

The story itself is really nice. [b] Although it features a rather small cast of characters, each have such vibrant personalities that you will remember them for months after the fact. [/b] I gripe that the story starts real slow and then speeds up, but it's generally made that way so you have time to bond with the characters, especially because you don't really know any part of the picture on this story going into it, not even Mae, the main character. Talking to characters always feels fresh and interesting, the dialogue is so witty and charming in a dry kind-of way, and I never felt bored at any point when people were talking.

That being said, the gameplay gets stale pretty fast outside of the minigames embedded in the story. Walking around a world that doesn't change for 5, 6, 7 hours doesn't feel great, and really hurts what should be decent replayability. You'll be jumping around a map for a couple minutes searching for some dialogue that you may or may not find. [b] Exploration, while it's there, isn't necessarily it's greatest strength. [/b] It's just not rewarding enough for players outside a couple achievements and a small laugh. Now the minigames, there's some good content. The music segments are amazing, the shoplifting minigames are great, the dumb one-off minigames you never see again feel so well-implemented you'd wonder why they didn't get their money's worth.

I think I've based the gameplay enough to be able to gush about the music and art of this game. [b] It oozes early 2000s aesthetic in its world, done in this really nice and creative almost construction paper craft-like art style that makes any screenshot of this game [i] instantly [/i] recognizable. [/b] The indie rock in this game will make you unable to focus on the fact that you have to play the music minigame to hear it. That's a good thing, I think (maybe?). It's good. Real good. So much so I might be finally breaking to buy the soundtrack, which I usually never do.

I liked the game. I have friends that LOVED the game. I don't think I was one of those people, but I DO suggest giving it a try. If nothing else, it's a game about learning that everything gets better with supportive friends. And that stealing is cool. Can't forget that.

Absolutely one of my favourite games ever - I adore this game. It probably isn't for everyone, but if the world resonates with you, you'll get so much from this game. One thing I will recommend is that this game is created and written in a way in which you will get back what you put in - both into the story and into the characters surrounding you in the world (and not just the main characters either). Every day is different, and every day is unique; take your time every day to explore and interact with the world and its characters, because once an opportunity passes, you'll lose it forever.

This game has gorgeous, vibrant characters and gorgeous, vibrant art. It has almost every variety of mini-game you could wish for, if only you go and seek them out. But this game's greatest talent is reminding you of what is important; life is short, and you need to keep your heart open to the people you love. And sometimes you'll need to fight for your future, even if the biggest enemy is yourself.

133307793.review:
(*Light spoilers lay ahead about themes and characters, in short buy and play the game. It's an experience that I haven't seen been done as well as it has here in the format of a video game.*)

This game has changed my life and is such a big part of me. I originally played NITW back in 2017 when it was released. I had been mourning the loss of a loved one who was my caregiver for most of my childhood which was very difficult for me. My family isn't so mindful of mental health so I was left alone to find ways to cope. I found this game on YouTube and played it myself, which soon after in one of my lowest moments, helped me. Made me laugh, cry and realize things that helped me move on from this low point. 

Its colorful and cozy atmosphere in a small quiet town littered with the orange leaves from the passing of fall was so pretty and the small moving community is so endearing. But the thing that resigned me the most would be the characters and the themes that this game has to offer. While this game looks cheerful and whimsical, which it is for the most part, it's still very down to earth. Characters have their day-to-day problems as well as their own baggage from past troubles that are very real, and they show it at times with moments of self-doubt, anxiety, anger, and just sadness of all forms. When I first played this game back then, characters such as Bea and Angus stood out to me for their views on life and the meaning of the universe, and their place in it, which I still believe in and follow today. A quote that I found to be very comforting in my time of grieving: [spoiler]"When my friends leave, when I have to let go, when this entire town is wiped off the map, I want it to hurt. Bad. I want to lose. I want to get beaten up. I want to hold on until I'm thrown off and everything ends."[/spoiler]

As of this writing, I am 19, turning 20 in July. A Lot has happened since the first time that I played this game. Now I'm transitioning into adulthood and done with school. I recently bought and played this game again on steam and like Mae coming back to her hometown I felt the same sense of nostalgia for this game. And even if it's been almost 6 years since I first experienced the story, I picked up on things that I now understand and find more relatable. Being considered an adult by the people around you but still feeling no different than you were not too long ago is the biggest one as well as the dread of working a 9 to 5, worrying about money, letting go of friends, and moving out into the world. 

This game reminds me that feeling scared about becoming an adult is okay. It's a big change for any person, but it's going to be alright in the end, which I needed to hear when I replayed this. I've taken almost everything this game has to offer to heart and have been living by it since my first time. From the shoe-gaze/dream pop band and indie coming-to-age aesthetic the game has to quite literally model myself as Angus. I have to thank NITW for changing my life, I've met many cool people because of it which include my best friends (love you guys). I still don't know exactly what I want to do with my life, but I'm alright with it. Because as long as I don't lose myself and keep what I find important close, I'll be alright.

So, to sum it up. Buy and play this game, it's worth it. The story is amazing, the characters/dialogue are funny, the gameplay is fun, and touches on dark/difficult subject matters. Who knows. Might be just what you need to have in your life just like how I needed it. Thanks for reading. <3

132664148.review:
Night in the Woods is one of the most memorable games I've ever played.

The extremely well-written characters are the biggest highlight, being often comedic, relatable, unexpectedly poignant, or just plain weird in a way that still feels human.

I also really appreciate how the story touches on real issues, but balances things by mixing in plenty of lighthearted and fantastical stuff that isn't meant to be taken seriously. You're given enough room to simply experience the story without wondering what moral it's trying to convince you of.

"[i]Okay,[/i]" you might be thinking, "[i]but what about the game's... gameplay?[/i]"

To put it bluntly: it's just a walking simulator with dialog trees the occasional minigame. Like really, there's not much to it. I found the writing and overall presentation so engaging that I didn't care, but that's something to keep in mind.

131014163.review: Where to even begin with this game... This game has TRULY changed my life in ways I don't have the ability to describe. The story, the characters, the music, the art...it is truly beyond words. The way this game touches on very real subjects but approaches them with a realistic yet artistic manner is beyond incredible. I especially hold this game close to my heart for the way it approaches Mae's depression and disassociation. I myself struggle with depersonalization and depression, along with a multitude of other issues, so to see depersonalization, something I haven't seen portrayed since I began struggling with it, described and shown in such a visually stunning way while still being aware and sensitive...it reached deep into my soul and touched me in a way not much else has. I am getting a Night in the Woods tattoo soon to immortalize how immensely important this game is to me, and I couldn't be happier. Seriously, you will not regret buying this game. Sure, it's a very story-heavy game with not as much gameplay mechanics that you would get in other games, but that just adds to the charm of it. I love this game more than I have loved any other game; I would not recommend any game above this.

130606924.review:
This is pretty amazing coming-of-age game. You are Mae the 20 year old anthropomorphised cat who dropped out of college for... reasons, and moved back home to her dying Rust Belt town to hang with her old friends, who have moved on with their lives while she's been away.

The game does a great job on characterisation: not just Mae, her parents and her friends, but even the NPCs and the town itself.  The closure of the mines and the factories has brought it to its knees, and every adult has seen their living standards decline, and their children have no hope.

The game's also not afraid to make you live through Mae being an insensitive and selfish idiot, hurting the people around her. She has a lot of growing up to do.

The game carefully segues between whimsical exploration and heavy emotional hits. This is also when you notice how well the music has been setting your mood, and you notice when it goes quiet and leaves you with nature sounds.

The main criticism I'd have is that the game spends so much time being a young-adult simulator, it forgets it has a plot, and it rushes it through in the second half of the game, which makes it feel more forced than it  actually is. There are a lot of lead-ins to the main plot scattered throughout the game, but you can miss them if you rush. And even then - gang of young adults solving mysteries? It's very Scooby-Doo.

Overall, amazing game, would do crimes with Gregg any time.

130128876.review:
Spoilers below etc etc, play the goddamn game before reading (seriously, trust me, just play the damn thing).

Night in the Woods is one of those games you play once with your hands and a thousand more in your mind. I mean the sheer depth of the characters alone is astounding, much less the complexity they meet the world with. I’m still thinking about some of the poetry they wrote, Selmers especially. It’s so rare to see an honest interpretation of the world, and this game is only honest. Even its lies are telling, not an obfuscation so much as a familiarly unavoidable reduction. The author has things to say; they cannot wait for perfection. My playthrough reflects this: I missed things, countless endearing and funny moments. Perhaps I was distracted by my phone and missed a pun, maybe I just zoned out at the wrong time. I mean, the path you choose on a given day decides who you’ll interact with and what you’ll learn about Possum Springs (more like AWESO-). Not coincidentally, this means that there are threads loose. I didn’t feed the rats enough, didn’t learn about Mae’s grandfather enough, didn’t go to the Falls with Angus (enough, I guess? The literary device got away from me). Somehow, despite being a lifelong anxious completionist and avid critic of “”ambiguous endings””, the indistinction feels right to me this time. The themes, carpe diem and excelsior and whatnot, create an ideal space to walk away with melancholic satisfaction. I have always loved autumn, especially that it dies. Night in the Woods loves this too, knows that we are all doomed, and yet! Yet it says: “You are faced with hordes of faceless enemies, bent on a sad, self-destructive goal?” “Take a nap,” it says, “and get some pizza. Your inevitable doom will be there in the morning.”

128254882.review:
I received this game as a birthday gift after putting it in my wishlist because a friend said it was a good game.
I kind of forgot I put it on my wishlist, but i was absolutely blown away when i got around to playing it, to the point where it dethroned my previous favorite game in just a single day of me playing it.

You take the role of Mae Borrowski, a college dropout  who returns to her tiny, decrepit hometown, where everything is familiar.



ATMOSPHERE
------------------
The atmosphere in this game captures the game perfectly, and has some underlying mental health themes as well. The visuals are gorgeous too, and really tie everything together with a simplistic yet beautiful art style.

MUSIC
---------------
Hoo boy, the music in this game is something else.
Alec Holowka did an amazing job with it, and every single track captures the theme perfectly.
The music is so good in fact, that I usually have it playing in the background while I play other games.

GAMEPLAY
-----------------
The basic gameplay loop consists of you exploring the town of Possum Springs, and hanging out with your old friends.
The town itself is rather small, but every day there are new things to see, so it rarely gets old.
There are also some slight platforming elements, and all sorts of simple-yet-fun minigames.

CHARACTERS
------------------
One of this game's biggest strongsuits are it's characters.
Each and every character is filled with so much personality that they practically feel like real people.
The  dialogue is also hilarious and I got so, so many good laughs out of it.

P.S: Gregg and Angus are precious and I would give the world for them. 

WORLD
-------------------
Despite having a (relatively) small map, the game world is shockingly lush and vibrant, with lots of things to explore and discover. Each day brings something new to the table and exploring the town is never a tedious task because of this, with the astounding atmosphere and music being a huge bonus.



RECCOMEND?
-------------------
Hell yes. This game is amazing and I would absolutely reccomend it.
I am proud to call Night in the Woods my favorite game of all time, and it's one of the few that I wish i could forget everything about just so that I could play through it again blind.


Alec Holowka
----------------------------
The review might be over, but im not done talking yet.

If you are unaware, Alec Holowka (Creator and composer of every soundtrack in this game) committed suicide a few years ago, following certain allegations from a known liar. He had everything taken away from him in an instant, all for a bit of online drama. (fuck you, Zoey Quinn)

Its not a fun thought by any means, but don't let it deter you from buying this masterpiece of his creation. Its an astounding game that will stick with me for the rest of my life.

Rest in peace, Alec, and thank you for creating this game.

BEFORE YOU DECIDE TO PURCHASE THIS, PLAY THIS GAME BLIND!!! TRUST ME.

3 Things I Negatively Assumed:
[olist]
[*]This game is for furries, and I'm no furry
[*]I have little attention span, and this looks like a dialogue heavy game which I dislike
[*]I bet the story is pretentious, predictable, and caters to hipsters
[/olist]

When I played the game, this is what I found out
[olist]
[*]These are the most adoring character designs I've ever seen (I'm still not a furry though)
[*]Engaged all the way through and immersed me in a way no other game could
[*]The characters are fun, layered and grounded within a realistic setting, enough to exist in the real world without heavily standing out (that is if they are turned into complete humans)

[*]Mae is such a relatable little goblin. I've never been deeply connected and have related with a video game character in my entire life, and yet it's Mae. 
[*]I know the town is implied to be somewhat sh1tty in the narrative, but I wanna live in this 2D Side-scrolling Multi-level Environment
[*]I've always sucked at rhythm games, and I still suck now
[*]This is my new comfort game, and I am committed to 100 percenting this, even if my fingers hurt practising for band practice!!!
[/olist]

This is a once in a lifetime experience that you cannot miss out if you're at least 20 years old or older.

Rest in peace, Alec Holowka

128016184.review:
+ Fun characters and dialogue.
+ Watch a sleepy small town slowly decay from the stranglehold of capitalism. 
+ Perfectly captures that twilight feeling of being past your teenage years, but not really old enough for the weight of adult responsibilities. Guess the whole game is a kind of twilight. The dull responsibilities of the day and the endless possibilities of night. The in between of waking and dreams, the living and the dead. Between civilized society and wild animals.
+ crimes.

- There are scenes and portions of the day you miss if you accept a "quest" and sometimes if you turn them down that was your only chance. As a completionist and someone who likes to explore, this is upsetting.
- Could have used a faster way to travel. Walking across town can get old when you've only got your stumpy sturdy legs.
- The climax fit the game thematically, but missed the mark with regards to your player character - Mae. None of the final events directly relate to Mae, so it feels like it came out of nowhere.

128006416.review:
I wanted to like Night in the Woods. The game was on my radar for a while, so I bought it when it was on sale. However, the first few hours have been extremely unenjoyable. The game seems to just drag on during dream sequences. The waking sequences are not much better: character movement feels less sluggish, sure, but the player is forced to traverse the same landscapes every day to get to the edge of town. The character interactions, or at least those that I had with Bea, felt too insubstantial to compensate for that, when I really thought about it.

There is nothing wrong with characters being unlikable per se, but Mae felt frustrating to play as a player. I understand that she is dealing with some serious mental health issues. (I am guessing that there is more revelation of that later in the game, from what I've heard, but it is already apparent from her departure from college, her daily routine, and the allusion to an incident in middle school.) But it is one thing to have to contend with that, and another to be roped into making incredibly terrible choices: tampering with evidence at a crime scene, shoplifting, being cruel and unempathetic to Bea. There are certainly ways to have characters act contrary to the wishes of the player, but this feels different.

I understand why people love Night in the Woods. I think someone who went into this expecting more outright storytelling and less player agency (or even adventuring or puzzle-solving) would love it, but that's not me.

128000113.review: good game, however it took me a veryyyy long time to complete. not because it was long but because it took a long time to reach any sort of plot that was obvious. The game throws you into Mae's life and you aren't really given much background on....well anything until the end. I guess it's supposed to give you a reason to keep playing but a lot of the time i felt the plot had no direction because of just HOW streched out it was. I didn't really understand what was happening a lot of time and only near the end did i catch onto the themes the game was presenting. I think it would have been easier for me if the game had visual objectives. For example, Mae's notebook could of had a "things to do" list suggesting things that you could do because i was unaware of what i was supposed to be doing and missed out on loaaads of character building as i didn't realise i could do certain things and ended up skipping days and also made like NO connection with Bea becuase i was unaware you could hang out with her. Overall it had a beautiful art style with some touching themes about coming of age and letting things go but i wish the game had a stronger direction and was spread out more evenly rather than the slow paced normal days that quickly ramped up into madness. I was hoping to enjoy this game more, i think i might with a second replay where i can dig a bit more and spend more time with the characters but yeah i found all the reveals like what Mae did at the football game and the cult underwhelming. Overall i'd say 6/10 though, was still good and i hope to connect with it on my second play through,

Night in the Woods o NITW es un juego con un estilo muy particular el cual siempre habia estado cierta manera presente o almenos lo tuve en la vista de la orilla de mi ojo desde 2017 cuando fue lanzado mas sin embargo verdaderamente nunca lo considere, principalmente por su estilo visual y un poco debido a los aires pretenciosos que sentia alrededor de esta obra y aquellos los cuales lo habian jugado ya que varios aseguraban que era una obra maestra oculta que los habia hecho sentir algo especial, cosa que verdaderamente se puede deber a muchos factores y variables en las vidas de quien lo ha jugado, algunas personas dicen que algunos personajes tenian personalidades tan parecidas a conocidos que era imposible no relacionarlos con su propia vida... y hasta cierto punto puedo entenderlo yo mismo he podido relacionar varias cosas de este juego con mi propia vida desde la relacion la protagonista con su madre hasta las mismas dudas que la protagonista pasa durante el juego mas sin embargo, es en esta ultima en la que muchos pueden relacionarse de una manera general, yo incluido.

Muchos jovenes hemos pasado por todas estas dudas la cuales no podemos contestarnos por nuestra experiencia y esto hace que nos confundamos y deambulemos no solo por nuestra mente sino nuestra vida, pero ya me estoy saliendo de el tema (una disculpa, pero cuando un juego me interesa bastante me gusta expandir un poco mi punto de vista, una disculpa si la redaccion talbes no es la mejor pero muchas gracias darle una oportunidad a mi reseña)

El juego toca temas bastante comunes para jovenes los cuales aun no hemos siquiera terminado de analizar completamente nuestro entorno pues se siente como si uno hubiera crecido en tan solo unas semanas una vez se es adulto o bueno almenos asi veo que es como se intenta representar al inicio (ojo que luego mencionare todo lo que se revela en el ultimo cuarto de la historia), la historia llega a presentarnos a puñado de personajes ("principales" por decirlo de alguna manera) a los cuales nos van mostrando cada vez mas su personalidad, actitudes, inquietudes y su relacion la protagonista, estas ultimas 2 en especial son las que se van tocando cada vez mas poco interactuemos con los personajes sin embargo, hay un gran problema con este ultimo y no es precisamente por el como se tocan los temas e inquietudes de estos, sino que verdaderamente jamas se termina de resolver alguna o no almenos no sin marginar algun personaje durante la historia lo cual simplemente termina dejandolo como si te dijeran "o mira pobre personaje a sufrido bastante es imposible que no te agrade" cosa que no era para nada necesaria, los personajes de por si podrian tener una historia no tan cruel y agradar de cualquier manera; (esperen un momento aqui las cosas que estoy diciendo se pueden malentender) pero esto es un problema que no causa verdaderamente ni las historias de los personajes, ni el guion, no... para nada, lo que verdaderamente causa para mi este problema es...

****Spoiler****

La corta duracion de la historia y su ultimo cuarto:
Enserio esto me dejo mucho que desear, en la ultima parte aceleran de la nada la trama vista en el final del 2do capitulo el cual estaba teniendo una buena progresion durante una buena parte del 3er capitulo mas sin embargo se empieza a notar que comienza a opacar la trama principalmente, hasta se sintiera que el juego cambia de genero a horror psicologico por algunas partes, cosa que no me termino de dejar un buen sabor de boca, estaba bastante interesado por como continuaba la historia del fantasma pero lo aceleran demasiado y toda la parte del culto siento que viniera de la nada lo cual me dejo pensando un momento, Que esta pasando?. otra cosa que viene algo de la nada tambien es el como la protagonista viene a contar algo de la nada este trauma que tuvo y que le hizo reaccionar de esa manera durante un partido de beibol, y todavia en cierta manera intentan relacionarlo con todo esto del culto espiritista ario que sale de la nada en el ultimo acto... todo muy extraño ciertamente.

***Fin de Spoiler***

Ya me he dejado llevar bastante y sinceramente quisiera contar mas pero creo que he dicho lo suficiente, incluso aunque casi todo lo que he hecho es criticar al juego yo digo que el criticismo es mas que necesario para cualquier cosa y a veces ver las cosas de manera objetiva es necesario para poder apreciar lo que verdaderamente un producto puede ofrecernos.

Pero sin embargo aun asi, Recomiendo este juego porque aunque tenga sus propios problemas aprecio mucho lo que cuenta o almenos intenta contar, una simple historia de unos amigos que se tienen unos a los otros en un mundo tan cruel y solitario el cual no importa cuantas veces te hiera, siempre habra aquellos los cuales estaran contigo no importa si estas bajo la lluvia o teniendo el peor momento de tu vida. 

PD: El soundtrack es 10/10 
PD2: si verdaderamente leiste esto hasta el final en verdad muchas gracias de corazon, los comentarios estan abiertos para cualquier cosa que se me haya pasado o quisiera comentar sobre mi reseña

126176723.review:
I deeply enjoyed this game for being very story-rich and having a lot of exploration and dialogue choices. There's also a lot of metaphors and themes that correlate to our real world around us which really make the gameplay close to home, quite literally.

You play as Mae, the main character who abruptly now has no future as a college dropout and returns to her hometown of Possum Springs, coming to find that even the past has oddly changed as well. Her home resembles that of a typical Rust Belt small town—economically-stagnating, people scraping by for any kind of work to make a living, a lot of reliable, good paying jobs from long before having left, and many shops and places of gathering having closed particularly when Mae was gone attending college. The setting captures a town ‘lost in time’ during autumn, forgotten for what glory it once had, and really induces a sort of nostalgic and contemplative mindset onto the player, which I find is best played when alone.

Progressively through the game you’ll discover that the story becomes more revealing and complex, slowly finding out the grim reasons behind why Mae left college along with learning more about her friends and family who were really well-written and have unique, memorable personalities. Depending on your choices, you can come to spend time with some more than others and see how their fates are much like Mae’s: uncertain, lost, not guaranteed, and their own pasts being dragged behind them in their own unique ways. There’s a great degree of emotional and conversational range with these characters when these existential, everyday subjects are brought up or encountered, which I really loved for feeling quite real. Regarding these things, the game does bring forth the challenges and importance of mental health and reaches into the player in a pretty powerful way: causing them to sympathetically reflect upon the conditions of the characters’ lives while also allowing the player to reflect thoughtfully of their own. Other challenges include financial problems, stress, arguing, relationship problems, crime, drinking, fanaticism, and the consequences of risk-taking, which again capture the real world setting with situations you’d find with actual people.

I also commend the soundtrack for being incredibly well-made and enjoyable for an indie game which was crowdfunded and laboriously crafted. 

If you like a nice slice of life story that can be both cozy and intense, then please give this game a try. You’ll really like it and appreciate the ambiance, music, diverse characters, and authentic plot.

126082072.review: 2022 and this game is still a favorite of mine alongside "Stray". Both the small town setting and Mae are relatable to me. And the character design and dialogue are charming and witty, along with a great story and soundtrack which I still find myself chilling out with from time to time. And it's great that this game has replayability, with each of Mae's friends having their own story to unlock as you choose to hang out with them one-on-one each new playthrough. Long story short, I can't recommend this game (And Stray, too!) enough

125084660.review:
++ There's a lot to explore
+ Replayability due to choice forks.
+ Characters are very charming.
+ The visuals are fantastic.
+ Good comedy
+ Best demonstration of awkward silence in a (dialogue) voiceless game.
+ Most of the minigames do work well, which is impressive, because big teams can often screw that up, but the mechanics themselves all seem to work, I just don't enjoy some as personal preference.
+ I could enjoy more experiences in this world (i.e. if the same creature-character types were used in another game, even if it was unrelated, but a similar gameplay and another story, I would be curious to experience it.) 
+ Worth its price. Plenty to experience for that value.

+ Overall story is compelling, 
- but the way it is stitched together sometimes feels empty: it could do with 2-3 more nights of context building, especially before [implying plot here that involves spoilers] happens. It just feels like a huge leap with, even reading the extra content, missing build.

[] Since your friends are all your friends, I really wish there was a way to do a run (maybe a new game plus) where you - IDK about how pro-crime it is, personal sticking point.
[] I can't tell how much of my experience is "tainted" by which path I took, so a couple criticisms might be due to what decisions I made, and not overarching problems.
[] I can't count it as a negative due to it being executed well, but it is kinda sad you can't make everyone fully happy at once.


- The dark parts are too dark on my computer, platforming them was sometimes really annoying.
- I don't like the Rockband sections at all, I wish you could opt to skip them (watch the video, but not have to do the playing--it would make it so you could read the lyrics and see the visuals, better, too for casuals.)
- The grabbing mechanic works, but feels slightly awkward.
- I don't know if it is choice-dependent or not, but some locations seem overly empty for the fact they "unlock" over time.
- Some replayability feels like it might be a chore.


Probably a lot more thoughts, IDK. Check it out.

125056576.review:
I honestly don't know how to feel about Night in the Woods.

Throught most of my playthrough, I wouldn't have recommended it. 
Much of the dialogue seems forced or childish. Like the characters aren't in their early twenties, but rather 13 or 14 years old.
This seems especially true for the main character, which sometimes changes personalities and is very frustrating.
A "I am very random" type of humour, which for me was unbearable at times.
In retrospect, I think it was intentional.

Yet still I persisted.
Because of the atmosphere of the game. Because of the great art direction.
And out of curiosity.

And in the end, the game resonated with me on some level.
I don't know exactly what I learned from it, but maybe that's not the point.
It didn't bring me to tears, or make me completely rethink my life (at least I think it didn't), but it sure will do that for some people.
Maybe it would do that for me as well, was I in a different place and/or time mentally and/or physically.

And I think it is an interesting experience.

124266640.review: While I understand the appeal of the story and that some people may deeply connect with it, there are simply too many gripes with Night in the Woods. Putting aside the most subjective views – some characters are behaving more like teenagers than young adults; some nonsense dialogues and humour mostly based on puns; lack of animations/sprites – the biggest issues are that the story progression drags too much and that there is close to non-existent gameplay. This story would be much better told with the book (that could go into more depth without the risk of falling into walking simulator territory) or a movie (which could tell the same in a 2-hour window and in a comparably engaging way). There is no justification of using the gaming medium in this way, the game got lost in the process.

124194561.review:
I. LOVE. THIS. GAME.
Night in the Woods (NITW) is absolutely perfect in every way. I never expected to be brought on such an emotional journey when I first picked it up. This game has affected me emotionally in such a way that I can't adequately describe it & do it justice, but I shall try. NITW has some great humour & an extremely lovable cast of characters (Bea is the best character by the way, I shall die on that hill), with a gorgeous artstyle & a bloody fantastic soundtrack to boot. This game throws you straight into the deep end of emotion & mental issues, with every character having issues that many can relate to & sympathise with. From Mae's psychotic episodes & paranoia to Gregg's ADHD, Bea's depression & Angus' childhood abandonment issues, every one of the main cast has suffered through something horrendous. While trying to pick up the peaces of Mae's crumbling life, you discover even more horrors awaiting, which is when the game goes from old friends trying to rekindle past bonds straight into existential dread of a cosmic horror, occultism & murder in a small town. I've played Bea's storyline many times now, and I just love it to death. You discover much about her life & while she seems extremely standoffish at first, you quickly begin to see that she has to deal with a lot more than she lets on (the same can be said about Gregg, Angus & Mae as well). Where this game broke me was actually in a side story, wherein a saddened, scared & anxious Mae falls asleep on a couch after following a trail of metaphorical breadcrumbs about her dead Grandfather. While she sleeps there, his ghost appears & starts to gently stroke her hair, as if comforting her, all the while a gorgeous soft song plays in the background. Having lost my Grandpa when I was 7, I felt all that emotion I felt then once more, and I bawled my eyes out for a long time. This game is beautiful & will stay with me forever, this I can say with complete honesty. Do yourself a favour & play this game, it's one of the few games I've played in my 20 years of life I can genuinely call a masterpiece.

124019512.review:
I have been playing this since 2018
Own it on every platform
Recently 100% it on my 11th playthrough

AND I STILL have yet to find a game that even comes close to the charm and beauty of this game. This game is beautiful in art design, setting, characters, music, and all else. 
Every character, even the side characters, have their own personality. Each feel worth talking to, and learning more about.
Gregg and Beatrice, no matter whom you decide to hang with. Each have their quirks, flaws, and perfections.
I love each of them, and it's clear they love you too.
This game has a lot of show don't tell philosophy, and they do it so magically.

Not to mention this game has a fully developed game inside of the game.
Called Demontower and not only is fun to play but has it's own set of endings. Along with the bass playing activities there's so much to see and do. exploring is fun, finding more characters to talk to is fun.

Mae is such an amazing character and she is so intriguing to learn about. Her struggles and problems feel unique. While still providing a sweet and caring person to her family and friends. 
She has a certain childlike naive personality. No matter how many times I play this I love seeing everyone again. 

If you've never played this game please do yourself the favor and try it. It's worth it no matter the price.

123789225.review:
Before anything else, R.I.P Alec Holowka. Thank you for being a part of this amazing experience.

The first time I played Night in the Woods was autumn of 2019. I was in a very similar situation as the protagonist Mae: I have just returned to my hometown and my parents' house after living abroad for half a year while getting through really difficult times. This made me instantly relate to Mae.

Mae was actually my biggest inspiration for picking up the bass. I have always wanted to play it but seeing a character that was so like me (her existentialism, mostly) being bad at something but still doing it, not letting her mental issues stop her, was very inspirational to me.

I replayed the game in autumn of 2022, because I had vaguely remembered the game as being autumn-themed and cozy, and I'm so glad that I did, because apparently I missed many things and misremembered others. NitW is definitely much more than what I initially remembered it as.
Getting deep into the story again reminded me why I loved it so much the first time.

Not only Mae but each character is great. They all have their own issues, hardships, things they won't talk about, things they struggle with, fears, and complex lives. Even the ones you only get to have a short conversation with. This made the world of NitW feel so real ([spoiler]I tried really hard not to break the illusion my own mind created of NitW's world, as Mae was talking about how her reality collapsed into shapes while playing a game[/spoiler]).

I will also add that Mae explains REALLY well what existentialism is, in a way that I was never able to articulate to others without seeming crazy.

I will always save a cozy spot in my heart for this game and its characters, and I might return to it in the future again as this is a comfort game for me.

123733261.review:
Excellent character-driven experience that will stay with you long after completion. The characters are nostalgia-addled small town queer kids (except Bea I guess but she seems pretty gay to me) trapped in the grating loop that is daily life in an Appalachian rust-belt town with an economic situation in decline. While their punk attitudes lead to a degree of rebellion and rejection of their more traditional culture, it becomes clear in the opening hours of the game that divorcing one's self from the past is easier said than done. Both for the characters, and the town.
Night in the Woods is a meditation on nostalgia, the future, and what those things mean for eccentric (And maybe a little bit criminal?) young-adults.

123627427.review:
While this game is basically a side scroller game, I very much enjoy the characters and the goofiness applied to them. While it is possible to beat the game in about 3 hours, if you actually wonder the town and interact with each character from your family to strangers in town to even sticking with one of your friend's routes, you start to feel for the characters in similar to your own life. While I'm sure people who want more action packed excitement may not have the patience for this kind of game, I'd say anyone who is interested in goofy, but good character development and story may enjoy this game. Especially as a game that tackles serious issues with mental and/or emotional issues and will unexpectedly relate to a lot of people struggling with such in life. I hope this review helps you to make your choice in buying this game or not.
P.S. Rest in peace Alec Holowka. I'm sorry that this had to happen to you after you made such a great game. Even today, those that have played it or are getting into now enjoy what you made. It's just a shame that this caused you to get the attention you didn't deserve. I hope this game can just continue to bring people happiness and help them through their struggles. People, I know pain is hard and life is pain, but please, don't believe that suicide should be a solution.

123081023.review:
Night in the Woods is quite possibly one of the best games I've ever played. I've played through it a few times over the years and every single time it feels as if I'm having some sort of life breakthrough. The game takes place in a depressed former industry town based on the Rust Belt. I've spent a fair amount of time in a city that is the epitome of a Rust Belt town and I can't even describe how accurate it is to real life. Even though the game has anthropomorphic characters, they're some of the most interesting and relatable characters in gaming today. 

Each segment of the game takes place over the course of one day, and you simply walk through the town and talk to the citizens of Possum Springs. This consist of the entirety of the gameplay, so the player can't go in with a mindset of wanting a platformer game. It requires patience to play Night in the Woods. I would essentially consider this game a visual novel with very slight point and click elements.

122920170.review:
An interesting game about a Mae a young cat finding herself in her old home after quitting college. Interesting story about reconnecting with her old friends. Change however is omnipresent and emerging and she has to tackle her insecurities and fears, while also trying to hold on her youthful, really fucked up and also criminal past. Main game 7.5 / 10.

Besides that, there is a mini game called Demontower, which is short but pretty good 9/10. 
However as long as you do not play on a trackpad you should finishi it in about 3 hours. It is rather easy especially the second to last forest ring-ghost boss, which you should be able to first try. (Imagine taking 500 hours just to beat this boss. LOL)

Also the game is really easy for achievement hunting, as long as you watch through the credits and get the last Bea entry and don't skip because you had to much coffee and not enough sleep. Imagine missing that and delaying your last achievement for 4 days or so and loosing a bet, even though you played the game 480h before the other one even started.

Jokes and Memes aside, i played this game with someone, who had a really rough couple of weeks lately. The game is typically not my genre,  but it was really fun trying it out and maybe I will come back to this types of games. I hope we could relieve at least some stress and maybe just maybe forget about the world for a little bit to get some rest. The game was really good and I want to thank the one who suggested it.

To sum up: I got to stab my best friend in the game -> 7.5/10

PS. I got forced to write that Review

-- XOXO Gossip Girl

121900697.review:
I started this game without any expectations, none. I know it's a popular game, but never have I really played a 2D side scrolling, story driven game. I played a lot of story games where actions/dialogues have concequences, but nothing like this. Nothing that just has text and without actual voice actors, etc. 
I expected to play it for about 25 minutes and be done with it.....

I was very, very wrong. Good god...What a journey this was.

I know you shouldn't judge anything before playing, but I just thought this wouldn't be something for me. But man...I fell in love with the characters so much. Even if it's all looking rather simplistic 2D, there's so much depth to everything... the choices you make, the things you do. The people you speak to. And everytime you wonder like "Where does this lead up to?" You keep on playing to find out the answers that haunt you. And everytime you think you've seen it all, you keep finding new pieces to the puzzle or...finding out stuff you hadn't done before. And the music...dude, the music is so good too. It really does justice to the atmospheres and situations.

And don't be fooled by the simplistic, whimiscal 'childish' aspect at first glance....It's all a facade. There are deeper, darker meanings behind all of it. I got very emotional at times, stuff hits like a truck. Or sat on the edge of my seat because it was so scary/exciting... but also laughed my ass off at some of the hilarious dialogue. It's sort of slice of life....but with a big mystery to it. Even if you think you understand everything, you'll still fall short of answers. There's always this cryptic emptiness, and I guess I'll really understand it all if I keep replaying. It's really worth it to play it over, try other dialogues, approach things differently and hang out with different friends. You really aren't done with one playthrough...

All n' all, I'm so happy I finally gave this game a chance. 25 minutes turned out to be playing this game every evening after work, to relax and escape into this world. Somehow an all too familiar world, but I enjoyed every bit about it.

121592952.review:
I play this game every fall, and though it's the same story every time, it feels like coming home. 

Possum springs reminds me of my own little town. One that you can bike across in 30 minutes flat. There's not a lot to do here, and everybody seems to be aiming to leave this place. I'm not yet out of high-school, but I am on the cusp of my Senior year. After it's done and gone, I'll be going off to college, presuming that I graduate on time. It feels like I'm standing on the edge of something big and great, yet uncertainty grips me. I'm unsure, I suppose.

I relate to Mae a lot in that regard. Mental health is a big factor for me, and I'm afraid I won't manage to make it through college without homesickness gripping me in the coming years. There will always be someone waiting for me at home, but everyone I'll have known from now and the past few years here will be gone. People from my childhood will move on with their lives. People already are. 

And I guess that's apart of it, isn't it? Life moves on, time waits for no-one. People who we think have it all together are one disaster away from splitting themselves apart, and we're all just trying to figure out what to do with ourselves. I haven't figured out what to do with myself yet, but... Strangely, I think that's alright.

This game makes me nostalgic. From it's music, to the small town gossip, and the way I can relate to it all. Mae doesn't know what to do, at 20 years of age, and neither do I, at newly 17. It's dialogue feels real, especially since I too would go and do stupid things with my friends after school, given that we had nothing better to do. We'd do things that were technically illegal and loiter and mess around. The music creates an atmosphere I can't explain, but it's a good one. 

All in all, this game has given me bigger perspective into things than I previously had. And it's brought me a lot of joy in replaying it, over and over again. It's nostalgic, and it's more important to me than I think I could explain. Thank you, NITW.

121057016.review:
Completely disappointed and bored with this game.

Purchased and started playing after I watched a talk about Yarn Spinner - the system behind Night In The Woods dialogs. It is an inspiring talk about the complexity of dialog system in the game.
I regret to say reality is far from what was promised. Rarely the game offers even 2 choices in a dialog, but when it does the difference is miniscule.
Dialogs are set in short chunks. Click again and again to get the next bit of pointless information push.
Along with static postures and non-diverse visuals of the npcs this creates a feeling that I'm pushing a button on a plushie toy with 2 or 3 cycling phrases.
There is no gameplay per se, NitW is about running around and searching for that npc whos dialog would move the game forward. It offers exploration options and "hidden" places that reward you with nothing but same empty comments of the protagonist about places or characters that you don't care about. Because the game hasn't told you why you should care.

This game appeals to a very niche audience, so you'll either love it or hate it. 120988170.review:
First off, I have to say I enjoyed this game. It's unique art style is charming and colourful, although the animation is incredibly basic the small world generally feels like a nice place to be. 

Gameplay & Controls
There is a platforming element to the game but its very simplistic and there's nothing particularly challenging about moving around. The three jumps in a row thing which makes your last jump a big one was largely superseded by the run and running big jump decades ago, so it's kinda strange to see that make a return.

The controls are fine but really odd. They use 'C' as the action button instead of the industry standard 'e' for absolutely no obvious reason and the game does not use the mouse at all. The last time I came across this type of control setup I was using a Commodore 64..

The controls and core mechanics are incredibly basic, with the sole focus on the story. The story is essentially an animated text adventure, where you walk to people and work your way through the speech bubble dialogues 

Story
This is pretty much the whole game here. You play an entitled 20 year old 'child' who has never had to work for anything in their life. The child in question is one of those kids who has always had everything they need but steals for fun anyway, and spends their spare time doing petty crimes. 'Crimes'. Yeh.. Shut up you little should really focus on the review. The game shows you this pretty early on and honestly, it made the main character incredibly un-likeable for me. 

Playing through the story you're aware that something bad happened and the main character basically left college for some reason, the story is incredibly slow to extract the reasoning behind this and doesn't ever really fully explain the back story to it. There are hints of possible mental illness in there but in all honesty it just comes across as a spoilt rich kid desperately unprepared for life who resorted to violence as their spoilt entitled life started to fall in on them. Yeah i get that there were some issues there but it all seemed like it was most likely due to a total lack of any real parenting than anything else.

Anyway **Spoiler alert**

The game then goes off on this wierd death cult tangent which is absolutely riddled with plot holes and is never fully explained. 39 missing people in a small town and only the local bobby is working on it? It just makes no sense, there is just no way they would have every got away with that. It would have made more sense if they'd just started it and only killed a couple of people. 

I really wanted there to be a really clever plot twist where the game concludes that the whole thing was an expression of MAE's insanity, and replaying it you actually see that it's all in Mae's head, but nope, deathcult.

The only way it would have made sense would have been if the whole plot, characters and world only existed in Mae's head.

I did enjoy it, but it felt fairly lazily written and I thought it could have been a lot better.

120789884.review:
Night in the Woods is one of a kind.

There isnt much going on gameplay wise, but the character and story, just WOW, the character felt so realistic, and interesting (more on that later)

The OST was really catchy, mostly relaxing, which is fitting, this game is kinda of a slow burner, so its ideal for those wanting a game you can play at your own pace.

The artstyle is beautiful, almost like something you would see in a children's picture book, its colorful, lively and also well animated. 

Like i mentioned earlier, this is a slow burner, most of the time you basically expend the game hanging around with other characters, speaking of, the game allows you to take choices at several points, mainly what to say, which can affect how the conversation will go, but theres also on which character you decide to hang around with, those being Bea (A gloomy and cold crocodile) and Greeg (An hyperactive delinquent fox) , allowing you to learn their story and relationship with the protagonist Mea (A dropout from collage, a cat), its possible to hang around other characters as well, but those are optional.

So now talking about the themes and characters, the game explores several psychological themes such has depression, wanting to fit in, wondering about your future, social anxiety, among others, and it does it SO WELL, this is what really sold me on this game, alongside its characters which explore these themes.

Mea the protagonist, is quite an interesting one, at first you might... not like her, but the game over time explores her relationship with others, as well as to who she is and what she has/had to go trough in her life, she is a deeply flawed character, and one i could really relate to, i cant say much more since that would get into spoiler territory, but she will grown on you. 

The game does have a couple of Minigames spread out, mainly two in particular, one being the "Music Practice" which plays kinda like Guitar Hero, where you gotta click on the notes on the correct timing, dont worry, this is mostly just messing around and you dont need to be good at it, mind you, the character will comment on your performance :P

The other being "Demontower", which is optional, this one plays like your usual dungeon crawler, but it can be quite hard.

The game does offer a quite a bit of replayability, like mentioned earlier, you take decisions at several points in the game, which affect how the story plays out, so you can do multiple runs to learn all the choices and learn about all the characters. 


Anyway, Night in the Woods is special, is one of those games that really gets you thinking and one everyone should give a try, specially those interested in psychology, who knows, it might even change your life. 

10/10.
